House of Zhao

è¶™æ°ä¹‹å…ˆï¼Œèˆ‡ç§¦å…±ç¥–ã€‚ è‡³ä¸­è¡ï¼Œç‚ºå¸å¤§æˆŠå¾¡ã€‚ å…¶å¾Œä¸–èœšå»‰æœ‰å­äºŒäººï¼Œè€Œå‘½å…¶ä¸€å­æ›°æƒ¡ä¾†ï¼Œäº‹ç´‚ï¼Œç‚ºå‘¨æ‰€æ®ºï¼Œå…¶å¾Œç‚ºç§¦ã€‚ æƒ¡ä¾†å¼Ÿæ›°å­£å‹ï¼Œå…¶å¾Œç‚ºè¶™ã€‚
The ancestors of the Zhao clan shared a common forebear with the Qin. This line reached Zhong Yan, who served as charioteer to Emperor Da Wu. In a later generation, Fei Lian had two sons. He named one E Lai, who served King Zhou. He was executed by Zhou forces. His descendants became the Qin clan. E Lai's younger brother was named Ji Sheng. His descendants became the Zhao clan.
2
å­£å‹ç”Ÿå­Ÿå¢ã€‚ å­Ÿå¢å¹¸æ–¼å‘¨æˆç‹ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºå®…çš‹ç‹¼ã€‚ çš‹ç‹¼ç”Ÿè¡¡çˆ¶ï¼Œè¡¡çˆ¶ç”Ÿé€ çˆ¶ã€‚ é€ çˆ¶å¹¸æ–¼å‘¨ç¹†ç‹ã€‚ é€ çˆ¶å–é©¥ä¹‹ä¹˜åŒ¹ï¼Œèˆ‡æ¡ƒæ—ç›œé©ªã€é©Šé¨®ã€ç¶ è€³ï¼Œç»ä¹‹ç¹†ç‹ã€‚ ç¹†ç‹ä½¿é€ çˆ¶å¾¡ï¼Œè¥¿å·¡ç‹©ï¼Œè¦‹è¥¿ç‹æ¯ï¼Œæ¨‚ä¹‹å¿˜æ­¸ã€‚ è€Œå¾åƒç‹åï¼Œç¹†ç‹æ—¥é¦³åƒé‡Œé¦¬ï¼Œæ”»å¾åƒç‹ï¼Œå¤§ç ´ä¹‹ã€‚ ä¹ƒè³œé€ çˆ¶ä»¥è¶™åŸï¼Œç”±æ­¤ç‚ºè¶™æ°ã€‚
Ji Sheng fathered Meng Zeng. Meng Zeng was favored by King Cheng of Zhou. He was also known as Zhai Gao Lang. Gao Lang fathered Heng Fu, who fathered Zao Fu. Zao Fu was favored by King Mu of Zhou. Zao Fu obtained a team of fine horses and, together with Tao Lin, stole the famed steeds Li, Hua Liu, and Lu Er. He presented them to King Mu. King Mu had Zao Fu drive the chariot on a western inspection tour. He met the Queen Mother of the West and enjoyed it so much he forgot to return. But King Xu Jian rebelled. King Mu daily galloped his thousand-li horses and attacked King Xu Jian, greatly defeating him. He then granted Zao Fu the city of Zhao. From this they became the Zhao clan.
3
è‡ªé€ çˆ¶å·²ä¸‹å…­ä¸–è‡³å¥„çˆ¶ï¼Œæ›°å…¬ä»²ï¼Œå‘¨å®£ç‹æ™‚ä¼æˆï¼Œç‚ºå¾¡ã€‚ åŠåƒç•æˆ°ï¼Œå¥„çˆ¶è„«å®£ç‹ã€‚ å¥„çˆ¶ç”Ÿå”å¸¶ã€‚ å”å¸¶ä¹‹æ™‚ï¼Œå‘¨å¹½ç‹ç„¡é“ï¼Œå»å‘¨å¦‚æ™‰ï¼Œäº‹æ™‰æ–‡ä¾¯ï¼Œå§‹å»ºè¶™æ°äºæ™‰åœ‹ã€‚
From Zao Fu down six generations came Yan Fu, known as Gong Zhong. In King Xuan of Zhou's time he fought the Rong and served as charioteer. During the battle of Qian Mu, Yan Fu rescued King Xuan. Yan Fu fathered Shu Dai. In Shu Dai's time, King You of Zhou was tyrannical. He left Zhou and went to Jin, served Marquis Wen of Jin, and began establishing the Zhao clan in the Jin state.
4
è‡ªå”å¸¶ä»¥ä¸‹ï¼Œè¶™å®—ç›Šèˆˆï¼Œäº”ä¸–è€Œï¼ˆç”Ÿï¼‰ï¼»è‡³ï¼½è¶™å¤™ã€‚
From Shu Dai onward, the Zhao lineage grew increasingly prominent. After five generations it reached Zhao Su.
5
è¶™å¤™ï¼Œæ™‰ç»å…¬ä¹‹åå…­å¹´ä¼éœã€é­ã€è€¿ï¼Œè€Œè¶™å¤™ç‚ºå°‡ä¼éœã€‚ éœå…¬æ±‚å¥”é½Šã€‚ æ™‰å¤§æ—±ï¼Œåœä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ã€Œéœå¤ªå±±ç‚ºç¥Ÿã€ã€‚ ä½¿è¶™å¤™å¬éœå›æ–¼é½Šï¼Œå¾©ä¹‹ï¼Œä»¥å¥‰éœå¤ªå±±ä¹‹ç¥€ï¼Œæ™‰å¾©ç©°ã€‚ æ™‰ç»å…¬è³œè¶™å¤™è€¿ã€‚
Zhao Su, in Duke Xian of Jin's sixteenth year, attacked Huo, Wei, and Geng. Zhao Su was the general who attacked Huo. Lord Huo Qiu fled to Qi. Jin had a great drought. They divined it and said 'Huo Tai Shan caused the calamity.' They sent Zhao Su to summon the lord of Huo from Qi and restore him, to conduct the Huo Tai Shan sacrifices. Jin again became bountiful. Duke Xian of Jin granted Zhao Su Geng.
6
å¤™ç”Ÿå…±å­Ÿï¼Œç•¶é­¯é–”å…¬ä¹‹å…ƒå¹´ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…±å­Ÿç”Ÿè¶™è¡°ï¼Œå­—å­é¤˜ã€‚
Su fathered Gong Meng, during the first year of Duke Min of Lu. Gong Meng fathered Zhao Shuai, styled Zi Yu.
7
è¶™è¡°åœäº‹æ™‰ç»å…¬åŠè«¸å…¬å­ï¼Œè«å‰ï¼› åœäº‹å…¬å­é‡è€³ï¼Œå‰ï¼Œå³äº‹é‡è€³ã€‚ é‡è€³ä»¥é©ªå§¬ä¹‹äº‚äº¡å¥”ç¿Ÿï¼Œè¶™è¡°å¾ã€‚ ç¿Ÿä¼å»§å’å¦‚ï¼Œå¾—äºŒå¥³ï¼Œç¿Ÿä»¥å…¶å°‘å¥³å¦»é‡è€³ï¼Œé•·å¥³å¦»è¶™è¡°è€Œç”Ÿç›¾ã€‚ åˆï¼Œé‡è€³åœ¨æ™‰æ™‚ï¼Œè¶™è¡°å¦»äº¦ç”Ÿè¶™åŒã€è¶™æ‹¬ã€è¶™å¬°é½Šã€‚ è¶™è¡°å¾é‡è€³å‡ºäº¡ï¼Œå‡¡åä¹å¹´ï¼Œå¾—ååœ‹ã€‚ é‡è€³ç‚ºæ™‰æ–‡å…¬ï¼Œè¶™è¡°ç‚ºåŸå¤§å¤«ï¼Œå±…åŸï¼Œä»»åœ‹æ”¿ã€‚ æ–‡å…¬æ‰€ä»¥ååœ‹åŠéœ¸ï¼Œå¤šè¶™è¡°è¨ˆç­–ï¼Œèªåœ¨æ™‰äº‹ä¸­ã€‚
Zhao Shuai divined serving Jin Xian Gong and the various gong zi. None were auspicious; He consulted the oracle about serving Prince Chong Er. It was auspicious, so he served Chong Er. Chong Er, because of the Li Ji disturbances, fled to the Di. Zhao Shuai followed him. The Di attacked Mao Jiu Ru and obtained two women. The Di married the younger daughter to Chong Er and the elder daughter to Zhao Shuai, who gave birth to Dun. Originally, when Chong Er was still in Jin, Zhao Shuai's wife also gave birth to Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Ying Qi. Zhao Shuai followed Chong Er in exile. Altogether nineteen years, they obtained return to the state. Chong Er became Duke Wen of Jin. Zhao Shuai became grandee of Yuan, resided at Yuan, and managed state affairs. The reason Duke Wen was able to return to the state and achieve hegemony was largely due to Zhao Shuai's strategies. This is recounted in the Jin annals.
8
è¶™è¡°æ—¢åæ™‰ï¼Œæ™‰ä¹‹å¦»å›ºè¦è¿ç¿Ÿå¦»ï¼Œè€Œä»¥å…¶å­ç›¾ç‚ºé©å—£ï¼Œæ™‰å¦»ä¸‰å­çš†ä¸‹äº‹ä¹‹ã€‚ æ™‰è¥„å…¬ä¹‹å…­å¹´ï¼Œè€Œè¶™è¡°å’ï¼Œè¬šç‚ºæˆå­£ã€‚
After Zhao Shuai returned to Jin, his Jin wife firmly insisted on welcoming the Di wife, and established her son Dun as the proper heir. The Jin wife's three sons all served below him. In Duke Xiang of Jin's sixth year, Zhao Shuai died and was given the posthumous name Cheng Ji.
9
è¶™ç›¾ä»£æˆå­£ä»»åœ‹æ”¿äºŒå¹´è€Œæ™‰è¥„å…¬å’ï¼Œå¤ªå­å¤·çš‹å¹´å°‘ã€‚ ç›¾ç‚ºåœ‹å¤šé›£ï¼Œæ¬²ç«‹è¥„å…¬å¼Ÿé›ã€‚ é›æ™‚åœ¨ç§¦ï¼Œä½¿ä½¿è¿ä¹‹ã€‚ å¤ªå­æ¯æ—¥å¤œå•¼æ³£ï¼Œé “é¦–è¬‚è¶™ç›¾æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…ˆå›ä½•ç½ªï¼Œé‡‹å…¶é©å­è€Œæ›´æ±‚å›ï¼Ÿã€ è¶™ç›¾æ‚£ä¹‹ï¼Œæå…¶å®—èˆ‡å¤§å¤«è¥²èª…ä¹‹ï¼Œä¹ƒé‚ç«‹å¤ªå­ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºéˆå…¬ï¼Œç™¼å…µè·æ‰€è¿è¥„å…¬å¼Ÿæ–¼ç§¦è€…ã€‚ éˆå…¬æ—¢ç«‹ï¼Œè¶™ç›¾ç›Šå°ˆåœ‹æ”¿ã€‚
Zhao Dun succeeded Cheng Ji and managed state affairs for two years. Then Duke Xiang of Jin died. The crown prince Yi Gao was young. Because the state had many difficulties, Dun desired to establish Yong, Duke Xiang's younger brother. Yong was then in Qin. They sent an envoy to welcome him. The crown prince's mother wept day and night and kowtowed, telling Zhao Dun: 'What crime did the former lord commit? You release his proper son and moreover seek a lord?' Zhao Dun was worried and feared that his clan and the ministers would attack and execute him. He then established the crown prince as Duke Ling and mobilized troops to block those welcoming Duke Xiang's younger brother from Qin. After Duke Ling was established, Zhao Dun increasingly monopolized the state's governance.
10
éˆå…¬ç«‹åå››å¹´ï¼Œç›Šé©•ã€‚ è¶™ç›¾é©Ÿè««ï¼Œéˆå…¬å¼—è½ã€‚ åŠé£Ÿç†Šè¹¯ï¼Œèƒ¹ä¸ç†Ÿï¼Œæ®ºå®°äººï¼ŒæŒå…¶å°¸å‡ºï¼Œè¶™ç›¾è¦‹ä¹‹ã€‚ éˆå…¬ç”±æ­¤æ‡¼ï¼Œæ¬²æ®ºç›¾ã€‚ ç›¾ç´ ä»æ„›äººï¼Œå˜—æ‰€é£Ÿæ¡‘ä¸‹é¤“äººåææ•‘ç›¾ï¼Œç›¾ä»¥å¾—äº¡ã€‚ æœªå‡ºå¢ƒï¼Œè€Œè¶™ç©¿å¼’éˆå…¬è€Œç«‹è¥„å…¬å¼Ÿé»‘è‡€ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæˆå…¬ã€‚ è¶™ç›¾å¾©åï¼Œä»»åœ‹æ”¿ã€‚ å›å­è­ç›¾ã€Œç‚ºæ­£å¿ï¼Œäº¡ä¸å‡ºå¢ƒï¼Œåä¸è¨è³Šã€ï¼Œæ•…å¤ªå²æ›¸æ›°ã€Œè¶™ç›¾å¼’å…¶å›ã€ã€‚ æ™‰æ™¯å…¬æ™‚è€Œè¶™ç›¾å’ï¼Œè¬šç‚ºå®£å­Ÿï¼Œå­æœ”å—£ã€‚
Duke Ling reigned for fourteen years and became increasingly arrogant. Zhao Dun urgently admonished him, but Duke Ling would not listen. When eating bear's paw that was not properly cooked, he killed the cook and had his corpse carried out. Zhao Dun saw it. Duke Ling became fearful as a result and wanted to kill Dun. Dun was usually benevolent and loved people. Once, a hungry man he had fed under the mulberry tree instead defended and saved Dun, allowing him to escape. Before he could leave the border, Zhao Chuan assassinated Duke Ling and established Hei Tun, Duke Xiang's younger brother. This was Duke Cheng. Zhao Dun returned again and managed the state's governance. The jun zi criticized Dun: 'As chief minister, he fled but did not go out of the border, returned but did not punish the traitor.' Therefore the Tai Shi wrote: 'Zhao Dun assassinated his lord.' During Duke Jing of Jin's reign, Zhao Dun died and was given the posthumous name Xuan Meng. His son Shuo succeeded him.
11
è¶™æœ”ï¼Œæ™‰æ™¯å…¬ä¹‹ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæœ”ç‚ºæ™‰å°‡ä¸‹è»æ•‘é„­ï¼Œèˆ‡æ¥šèŠç‹æˆ°æ²³ä¸Šã€‚ æœ”å¨¶æ™‰æˆå…¬å§Šç‚ºå¤«äººã€‚
Zhao Shuo, in Duke Jing of Jin's third year, served as Jin's lower army general to save Zheng, and battled with King Zhuang of Chu on the river. Shuo married Duke Cheng of Jin's elder sister as his wife.
12
æ™‰æ™¯å…¬ä¹‹ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œå¤§å¤«å± å²¸è³ˆæ¬²èª…è¶™æ°ã€‚ åˆï¼Œè¶™ç›¾åœ¨æ™‚ï¼Œå¤¢è¦‹å”å¸¶æŒè¦è€Œå“­ï¼Œç”šæ‚²ï¼› å·²è€Œç¬‘ï¼Œæ‹Šæ‰‹ä¸”æ­Œã€‚ ç›¾åœä¹‹ï¼Œå…†çµ•è€Œå¾Œå¥½ã€‚ è¶™å²æ´å ä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å¤¢ç”šæƒ¡ï¼Œéå›ä¹‹èº«ï¼Œä¹ƒå›ä¹‹å­ï¼Œç„¶äº¦å›ä¹‹å’ã€‚ è‡³å­«ï¼Œè¶™å°‡ä¸–ç›Šè¡°ã€‚ã€ å± å²¸è³ˆè€…ï¼Œå§‹æœ‰å¯µæ–¼éˆå…¬ï¼ŒåŠè‡³æ–¼æ™¯å…¬è€Œè³ˆç‚ºå¸å¯‡ï¼Œå°‡ä½œé›£ï¼Œä¹ƒæ²»éˆå…¬ä¹‹è³Šä»¥è‡´è¶™ç›¾ï¼Œéå‘Šè«¸å°‡æ›°ï¼šã€Œç›¾é›–ä¸çŸ¥ï¼ŒçŒ¶ç‚ºè³Šé¦–ã€‚ ä»¥è‡£å¼’å›ï¼Œå­å­«åœ¨æœï¼Œä½•ä»¥æ‡²ç½ªï¼Ÿ è«‹èª…ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ éŸ“å¥æ›°ï¼šã€Œéˆå…¬é‡è³Šï¼Œè¶™ç›¾åœ¨å¤–ï¼Œå¾å…ˆå›ä»¥ç‚ºç„¡ç½ªï¼Œæ•…ä¸èª…ã€‚ ä»Šè«¸å›å°‡èª…å…¶å¾Œï¼Œæ˜¯éå…ˆå›ä¹‹æ„è€Œä»Šå¦„èª…ã€‚ å¦„èª…è¬‚ä¹‹äº‚ã€‚ è‡£æœ‰å¤§äº‹è€Œå›ä¸èï¼Œæ˜¯ç„¡å›ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å± å²¸è³ˆä¸è½ã€‚ éŸ“å¥å‘Šè¶™æœ”è¶£äº¡ã€‚ æœ”ä¸è‚¯ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå­å¿…ä¸çµ•è¶™ç¥€ï¼Œæœ”æ­»ä¸æ¨ã€‚ã€ éŸ“å¥è¨±è«¾ï¼Œç¨±ç–¾ä¸å‡ºã€‚ è³ˆä¸è«‹è€Œæ“…èˆ‡è«¸å°‡æ”»è¶™æ°æ–¼ä¸‹å®®ï¼Œæ®ºè¶™æœ”ã€è¶™åŒã€è¶™æ‹¬ã€è¶™å¬°é½Šï¼Œçš†æ»…å…¶æ—ã€‚
In Duke Jing of Jin's third year, the grandee Tu An Jia desired to execute the Zhao clan. Initially, when Zhao Dun was alive, he dreamed he saw Shu Dai holding his waist and crying, very sad; Then he laughed, clapped his hands, and sang. Dun consulted the oracle about it. The omen was broken but then became favorable. Zhao Shi Yuan interpreted it: 'This dream is very bad. It is not the lord's body, but the lord's son. However, it is also the lord's guilt. To the grandson, the Zhao will moreover decline through the generations.' Tu An Jia began having favor with Ling Gong. When it came to Jing Gong, Jia became Si Kou. He was about to make difficulty, so he punished Ling Gong's traitor to implicate Zhao Dun. He broadly told the various generals: 'Though Dun did not know, he is still the traitor's head. A minister assassinated his lord. His descendants are in court. How to punish the crime? Request to execute them.' Han Jue said: 'Ling Gong met the traitor. Zhao Dun was outside. My former lord considered him innocent, therefore did not execute him. Now you lords are about to execute his descendants. This is not the former lord's intention and moreover now recklessly execute. Reckless execution is called rebellion. A minister has great matters but the lord does not hear. This is without a lord.' Tu An Jia would not listen. Han Jue told Zhao Shuo to hurry and flee. Shuo was not willing: 'You must not cut off the Zhao sacrifices. Shuo will die without regret.' Han Jue agreed. He claimed illness and did not go out. Jia did not ask permission but arbitrarily joined with the various generals to attack the Zhao clan at the lower palace. He killed Zhao Shuo, Zhao Tong, Zhao Kuo, and Zhao Ying Qi. He extinguished all their clans.
13
è¶™æœ”å¦»æˆå…¬å§Šï¼Œæœ‰éºè…¹ï¼Œèµ°å…¬å®®åŒ¿ã€‚ è¶™æœ”å®¢æ›°å…¬å­«æµè‡¼ï¼Œæµè‡¼è¬‚æœ”å‹äººç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œèƒ¡ä¸æ­»ï¼Ÿã€ ç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œæœ”ä¹‹å©¦æœ‰éºè…¹ï¼Œè‹¥å¹¸è€Œç”·ï¼Œå¾å¥‰ä¹‹ï¼› å³å¥³ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¾å¾æ­»è€³ã€‚ã€ å±…ç„¡ä½•ï¼Œè€Œæœ”å©¦å…èº«ï¼Œç”Ÿç”·ã€‚ å± å²¸è³ˆèä¹‹ï¼Œç´¢æ–¼å®®ä¸­ã€‚ å¤«äººç½®å…’å±ç½…ç¥æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™å®—æ»…ä¹ï¼Œè‹¥è™Ÿï¼› å³ä¸æ»…ï¼Œè‹¥ç„¡è²ã€‚ã€ åŠç´¢ï¼Œå…’ç«Ÿç„¡è²ã€‚ å·²è„«ï¼Œç¨‹å¬°è¬‚å…¬å­«æµè‡¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šä¸€ç´¢ä¸å¾—ï¼Œå¾Œå¿…ä¸”å¾©ç´¢ä¹‹ï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿã€ å…¬å­«æµè‡¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œç«‹å­¤èˆ‡æ­»å­°é›£ï¼Ÿã€ ç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­»æ˜“ï¼Œç«‹å­¤é›£è€³ã€‚ã€ å…¬å­«æµè‡¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ°å…ˆå›é‡å­åšï¼Œå­å½Šç‚ºå…¶é›£è€…ï¼Œå¾ç‚ºå…¶æ˜“è€…ï¼Œè«‹å…ˆæ­»ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒäºŒäººè¬€å–ä»–äººå¬°å…’è² ä¹‹ï¼Œè¡£ä»¥æ–‡è‘†ï¼ŒåŒ¿å±±ä¸­ã€‚ ç¨‹å¬°å‡ºï¼Œè¬¬è¬‚è«¸å°‡è»æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¬°ä¸è‚–ï¼Œä¸èƒ½ç«‹è¶™å­¤ã€‚ èª°èƒ½èˆ‡æˆ‘åƒé‡‘ï¼Œå¾å‘Šè¶™æ°å­¤è™•ã€‚ã€ è«¸å°‡çš†å–œï¼Œè¨±ä¹‹ï¼Œç™¼å¸«éš¨ç¨‹å¬°æ”»å…¬å­«æµè‡¼ã€‚ æµè‡¼è¬¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œå°äººå“‰ç¨‹å¬°ï¼ æ˜”ä¸‹å®®ä¹‹é›£ä¸èƒ½æ­»ï¼Œèˆ‡æˆ‘è¬€åŒ¿è¶™æ°å­¤å…’ï¼Œä»Šåˆè³£æˆ‘ã€‚ ç¸±ä¸èƒ½ç«‹ï¼Œè€Œå¿è³£ä¹‹ä¹ï¼ã€ æŠ±å…’å‘¼æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©ä¹å¤©ä¹ï¼ è¶™æ°å­¤å…’ä½•ç½ªï¼Ÿ è«‹æ´»ä¹‹ï¼Œç¨æ®ºæµè‡¼å¯ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ è«¸å°‡ä¸è¨±ï¼Œé‚æ®ºæµè‡¼èˆ‡å­¤å…’ã€‚ è«¸å°‡ä»¥ç‚ºè¶™æ°å­¤å…’è‰¯å·²æ­»ï¼Œçš†å–œã€‚ ç„¶è¶™æ°çœŸå­¤ä¹ƒååœ¨ï¼Œç¨‹å¬°å’èˆ‡ä¿±åŒ¿å±±ä¸­ã€‚
Zhao Shuo's wife, Duke Cheng's elder sister, was pregnant with his posthumous child. She fled and hid in the palace. Zhao Shuo's guest was named Gong Sun Chu Jiu. Chu Jiu told Shuo's friend Cheng Ying: 'Why not die?' Cheng Ying said: 'Shuo's wife has a posthumous child. If fortunately it is male, I will support him; If female, I will slowly die.' Before long, Shuo's wife gave birth to a male child. Tu An Jia heard of it and searched in the palace. The lady placed the child and scolded the crevice diviner: 'Is the Zhao clan extinguished? If so, cry; If not extinguished, be without sound.' When they searched, the child was miraculously silent. Having already escaped, Cheng Ying told Gong Sun Chu Jiu: 'Now one search did not obtain it. Later they will certainly search again. What to do?' Gong Sun Chu Jiu said: 'Establishing an orphan and dying - which is more difficult?' Cheng Ying said: 'Dying is easy. Establishing an orphan is difficult.' Gong Sun Chu Jiu said: 'The Zhao clan's former lord treated you generously. You be strong and do the difficult one. I will do the easy one. I request to die first.' So the two plotted to take someone else's infant and carry it away. They wrapped it in an embroidered blanket and hid it in the mountains. Cheng Ying went out and falsely told the various generals: 'Ying is unworthy. I cannot establish the Zhao orphan. Who can give me a thousand in gold? I will tell the Zhao clan orphan's place.' All the generals were delighted. They agreed and mobilized their troops to follow Cheng Ying in attacking Gong Sun Chu Jiu. Chu Jiu falsely said: 'What a little man is Cheng Ying! During the earlier disaster at the Lower Palace, he refused to die with us. He plotted with me to hide the Zhao orphan. Now he's betraying me. Even if he cannot establish it, how can he endure selling it!' He embraced the child and called: 'Heaven, oh Heaven! What crime has the Zhao clan orphan child? Request to save it. Alone killing Chu Jiu is acceptable.' The generals refused. They then killed Chu Jiu and the orphan child. The generals believed the Zhao orphan was truly dead. They were all delighted. But the true Zhao orphan was still alive. In the end, Cheng Ying hid with him in the mountains.
14
å±…åäº”å¹´ï¼Œæ™‰æ™¯å…¬ç–¾ï¼Œåœä¹‹ï¼Œå¤§æ¥­ä¹‹å¾Œä¸é‚è€…ç‚ºç¥Ÿã€‚ æ™¯å…¬å•éŸ“å¥ï¼Œå¥çŸ¥è¶™å­¤åœ¨ï¼Œä¹ƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤§æ¥­ä¹‹å¾Œåœ¨æ™‰çµ•ç¥€è€…ï¼Œå…¶è¶™æ°ä¹ï¼Ÿ å¤«è‡ªä¸­è¡è€…çš†å¬´å§“ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸­è¡äººé¢é³¥å™£ï¼Œé™ä½æ®·å¸å¤§æˆŠï¼ŒåŠå‘¨å¤©å­ï¼Œçš†æœ‰æ˜å¾·ã€‚ ä¸‹åŠå¹½å²ç„¡é“ï¼Œè€Œå”å¸¶å»å‘¨é©æ™‰ï¼Œäº‹å…ˆå›æ–‡ä¾¯ï¼Œè‡³äºæˆå…¬ï¼Œä¸–æœ‰ç«‹åŠŸï¼Œæœªå˜—çµ•ç¥€ã€‚ ä»Šå¾å›ç¨æ»…è¶™å®—ï¼Œåœ‹äººå“€ä¹‹ï¼Œæ•…è¦‹é¾œç­–ã€‚ å”¯å›åœ–ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ™¯å…¬å•ï¼šã€Œè¶™å°šæœ‰å¾Œå­å­«ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ éŸ“å¥å…·ä»¥å¯¦å‘Šã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯æ™¯å…¬ä¹ƒèˆ‡éŸ“å¥è¬€ç«‹è¶™å­¤å…’ï¼Œå¬è€ŒåŒ¿ä¹‹å®®ä¸­ã€‚ è«¸å°‡å…¥å•ç–¾ï¼Œæ™¯å…¬å› éŸ“å¥ä¹‹çœ¾ä»¥è„…è«¸å°‡è€Œè¦‹è¶™å­¤ã€‚ è¶™å­¤åæ›°æ­¦ã€‚ è«¸å°‡ä¸å¾—å·²ï¼Œä¹ƒæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜”ä¸‹å®®ä¹‹é›£ï¼Œå± å²¸è³ˆç‚ºä¹‹ï¼ŒçŸ¯ä»¥å›å‘½ï¼Œå¹¶å‘½ç¾¤è‡£ã€‚ éç„¶ï¼Œå­°æ•¢ä½œé›£ï¼ å¾®å›ä¹‹ç–¾ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£å›ºä¸”è«‹ç«‹è¶™å¾Œã€‚ ä»Šå›æœ‰å‘½ï¼Œç¾¤è‡£ä¹‹é¡˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯å¬è¶™æ­¦ã€ç¨‹å¬°éæ‹œè«¸å°‡ï¼Œé‚åèˆ‡ç¨‹å¬°ã€è¶™æ­¦æ”»å± å²¸è³ˆï¼Œæ»…å…¶æ—ã€‚ å¾©èˆ‡è¶™æ­¦ç”°é‚‘å¦‚æ•…ã€‚
Fifteen years later, Duke Jing of Jin fell ill. When they consulted the oracle, it revealed that descendants of great achievers who had failed were causing the misfortune. Jing Gong asked Han Jue. Jue knew the Zhao orphan was there, so he said: 'Great achievement descendants in Jin whose sacrifices were cut off - perhaps the Zhao clan? Indeed, all descendants of Zhong Yan bear the Ying surname. Zhong Yan had a human face but a bird's beak. He descended to assist Emperor Da Wu of the Yin and the Zhou kings. All possessed bright virtue. This continued down to the wicked Kings You and Li. Then Shu Dai left Zhou and went to Jin, serving Duke Wen and on to Duke Cheng. Generation after generation they achieved merit and never ceased their sacrifices. Now my lord alone has destroyed the Zhao clan. The people of the state grieve for them. That's why it appeared in the turtle-shell divination. Only the lord should plan it.' Jing Gong asked: 'Does Zhao still have descendant sons?' Han Jue told him everything truthfully. Thereupon Duke Jing plotted with Han Jue to establish the Zhao orphan as heir. He summoned him and hid him in the palace. When the generals came to inquire about the duke's illness, Duke Jing used Han Jue's armed followers to intimidate them and reveal the Zhao orphan. The Zhao orphan was given the name Wu. The various generals had no alternative, so they said: 'The former lower palace difficulty was done by Tu An Jia. He falsely used the lord's command and included ordering the group of ministers. If not so, who would dare make difficulty! If not for the lord's illness, the ministers would surely have requested to establish Zhao descendants. Now the lord has a command. It is the group of ministers' wish.' Thereupon he summoned Zhao Wu and Cheng Ying. They bowed to all the generals, then turned around and joined with Cheng Ying and Zhao Wu to attack Tu An Jia, wiping out his entire clan. He restored Zhao Wu's lands and cities to their former extent.

åŠè¶™æ­¦å† ï¼Œç‚ºæˆäººï¼Œç¨‹å¬°ä¹ƒè¾­è«¸å¤§å¤«ï¼Œè¬‚è¶™æ­¦æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜”ä¸‹å®®ä¹‹é›£ï¼Œçš†èƒ½æ­»ã€‚ æˆ‘éä¸èƒ½æ­»ï¼Œæˆ‘æ€ç«‹è¶™æ°ä¹‹å¾Œã€‚ ä»Šè¶™æ­¦æ—¢ç«‹ï¼Œç‚ºæˆäººï¼Œå¾©æ•…ä½ï¼Œæˆ‘å°‡ä¸‹å ±è¶™å®£å­Ÿèˆ‡å…¬å­«æµè‡¼ã€‚ã€ è¶™æ­¦å•¼æ³£é “é¦–å›ºè«‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¦é¡˜è‹¦ç­‹éª¨ä»¥å ±å­è‡³æ­»ï¼Œè€Œå­å¿å»æˆ‘æ­»ä¹ï¼ã€ ç¨‹å¬°æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ã€‚ å½¼ä»¥æˆ‘ç‚ºèƒ½æˆäº‹ï¼Œæ•…å…ˆæˆ‘æ­»ï¼› ä»Šæˆ‘ä¸å ±ï¼Œæ˜¯ä»¥æˆ‘äº‹ç‚ºä¸æˆã€‚ã€ é‚è‡ªæ®ºã€‚ è¶™æ­¦æœé½Šè¡°ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œç‚ºä¹‹ç¥­é‚‘ï¼Œæ˜¥ç§‹ç¥ ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸–ä¸–å‹¿çµ•ã€‚
When Zhao Wu was capped and became an adult, Cheng Ying then resigned from the various grandees and told Zhao Wu: 'In the former lower palace difficulty, all could have died. I was not incapable of dying. I wanted to establish descendants of the Zhao clan. Now Zhao Wu is already established and has become an adult, recovering his former position. I will below report to Zhao Xuan Meng and Gong Sun Chu Jiu.' Zhao Wu wept and kowtowed, firmly requesting: 'Wu wishes to toil my muscles and bones to repay you until death, but how can you endure leaving me to die!' Cheng Ying said: 'This cannot be.' They considered me able to complete affairs, therefore they died first for me; Now if I do not repay, this makes my affairs not completed.' He then took his own life. Zhao Wu wore mourning for three years. He established sacrificial cities for them and performed rites in spring and autumn, never to be discontinued through the generations.

Eleven years after the Zhao clan regained their position, Duke Li of Jin killed his three ministers of the Xi clan. Luan Shu feared he would be next, so he assassinated his lord Duke Li and instead established Zhou, the great-grandson of Duke Xiang. This was Duke Dao. From this time on, the ministers of Jin gradually grew powerful.

è¶™æ­¦çºŒè¶™å®—äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰å¹³å…¬ç«‹ã€‚ å¹³å…¬åäºŒå¹´ï¼Œè€Œè¶™æ­¦ç‚ºæ­£å¿ã€‚ åä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œå³å»¶é™µå­£å­ä½¿æ–¼æ™‰ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‰åœ‹ä¹‹æ”¿å’æ­¸æ–¼è¶™æ­¦å­ã€éŸ“å®£å­ã€é­ç»å­ä¹‹å¾ŒçŸ£ã€‚ã€ è¶™æ­¦æ­»ï¼Œè¬šç‚ºæ–‡å­ã€‚
Zhao Wu carried on the Zhao lineage for twenty-seven years. Duke Ping of Jin ascended the throne. In the twelfth year of Duke Ping's reign, Zhao Wu became the chief minister. In the thirteenth year, Wu's Yan Ling Ji Zi was envoy to Jin and said: 'Jin state's governance will finally belong to the descendants of Zhao Wu Zi, Han Xuan Zi, and Wei Xian Zi.' Zhao Wu died and was given the posthumous name Wen Zi.

Wen Zi fathered Jing Shu. During Jing Shu's time, Duke Jing of Qi sent Yan Ying as envoy to Jin, where Yan Ying conversed with Shu Xiang of Jin. During Zhao Jian Zi's tenure, in the ninth year of Duke Qing of Jin's reign, Jian Zi was preparing to assemble the feudal lords to defend Zhou. The following year, he restored King Jing of Zhou to his capital, to avoid the affair of Di Zi Chao.

In the twelfth year of Duke Qing of Jin's reign, the six ministers legally executed the noble clans of Qi and Yang She. They divided their territories into ten counties, with each of the six ministers appointing members of their own clans as magistrates. From this time on, the house of Jin grew increasingly weak.

Thirteen years later, the treacherous minister Yang Hu of Lu came seeking refuge. Zhao Jian Zi accepted a bribe and treated him generously.

è¶™ç°¡å­ç–¾ï¼Œäº”æ—¥ä¸çŸ¥äººï¼Œå¤§å¤«çš†æ‡¼ã€‚ é†«æ‰éµ²è¦–ä¹‹ï¼Œå‡ºï¼Œè‘£å®‰äºå•ã€‚ æ‰éµ²æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¡€è„ˆæ²»ä¹Ÿï¼Œè€Œä½•æ€ªï¼ åœ¨æ˜”ç§¦ç¹†å…¬å˜—å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œä¸ƒæ—¥è€Œå¯¤ã€‚ å¯¤ä¹‹æ—¥ï¼Œå‘Šå…¬å­«æ”¯èˆ‡å­è¼¿æ›°ï¼šã€æˆ‘ä¹‹å¸æ‰€ç”šæ¨‚ã€‚ å¾æ‰€ä»¥ä¹…è€…ï¼Œé©æœ‰å­¸ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¸å‘Šæˆ‘ï¼šã€Œæ™‰åœ‹å°‡å¤§äº‚ï¼Œäº”ä¸–ä¸å®‰ï¼› å…¶å¾Œå°‡éœ¸ï¼Œæœªè€è€Œæ­»ï¼› éœ¸è€…ä¹‹å­ä¸”ä»¤è€Œåœ‹ç”·å¥³ç„¡åˆ¥ã€‚ã€ã€ å…¬å­«æ”¯æ›¸è€Œè—ä¹‹ï¼Œç§¦è®–æ–¼æ˜¯å‡ºçŸ£ã€‚ ç»å…¬ä¹‹äº‚ï¼Œæ–‡å…¬ä¹‹éœ¸ï¼Œè€Œè¥„å…¬æ•—ç§¦å¸«æ–¼æ®½è€Œæ­¸ç¸±æ·«ï¼Œæ­¤å­ä¹‹æ‰€èã€‚ ä»Šä¸»å›ä¹‹ç–¾èˆ‡ä¹‹åŒï¼Œä¸å‡ºä¸‰æ—¥ç–¾å¿…é–’ï¼Œé–’å¿…æœ‰è¨€ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€
Zhao Jian Zi fell gravely ill. For five days he was unconscious. All his ministers were terrified. The physician Bian Que examined him and left. Dong An Yu asked what he thought. Bian Que said: 'The blood vessels are orderly. Why strange! In ancient times, Duke Mu of Qin once suffered the same condition. He awoke after seven days. On the day he awoke, he told Gong Sun Zhi and Zi Yu: 'I was very happy at the Di's place. The reason I lingered was that I was engaged in study. The Di told me: 'Jin state will have great chaos. Five generations will not be peaceful; Its later will achieve hegemony, but die before old age; The hegemon's son will moreover make your state have no distinction between male and female.' Gong Sun Zhi wrote it down and concealed it. Thus the prophecy concerning Qin was revealed. The disorders under Duke Xian, the hegemony under Duke Wen, Duke Xiang's victory over Qin at Xiao followed by his dissolute return - these are things you have heard of. Now the lord's illness is the same as it. Not exceeding three days the illness will certainly recover. Recovery will certainly bring words.'

å±…äºŒæ—¥åŠï¼Œç°¡å­å¯¤ã€‚ èªå¤§å¤«æ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘ä¹‹å¸æ‰€ç”šæ¨‚ï¼Œèˆ‡ç™¾ç¥æ¸¸æ–¼éˆå¤©ï¼Œå»£æ¨‚ä¹å¥è¬èˆï¼Œä¸é¡ä¸‰ä»£ä¹‹æ¨‚ï¼Œå…¶è²å‹•äººå¿ƒã€‚ æœ‰ä¸€ç†Šæ¬²ä¾†æ´æˆ‘ï¼Œå¸å‘½æˆ‘å°„ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸­ç†Šï¼Œç†Šæ­»ã€‚ åˆæœ‰ä¸€ç¾†ä¾†ï¼Œæˆ‘åˆå°„ä¹‹ï¼Œä¸­ç¾†ï¼Œç¾†æ­»ã€‚ å¸ç”šå–œï¼Œè³œæˆ‘äºŒç¬¥ï¼Œçš†æœ‰å‰¯ã€‚ å¾è¦‹å…’åœ¨å¸å´ï¼Œå¸å±¬æˆ‘ä¸€ç¿ŸçŠ¬ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€åŠè€Œå­ä¹‹å£¯ä¹Ÿï¼Œä»¥è³œä¹‹ã€‚ã€ å¸å‘Šæˆ‘ï¼šã€æ™‰åœ‹ä¸”ä¸–è¡°ï¼Œä¸ƒä¸–è€Œäº¡ï¼Œå¬´å§“å°‡å¤§æ•—å‘¨äººæ–¼èŒƒé­ä¹‹è¥¿ï¼Œè€Œäº¦ä¸èƒ½æœ‰ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šä½™æ€è™èˆœä¹‹å‹³ï¼Œé©ä½™å°‡ä»¥å…¶èƒ„å¥³å­Ÿå§šé…è€Œä¸ƒä¸–ä¹‹å­«ã€‚ã€ã€ è‘£å®‰äºå—è¨€è€Œæ›¸è—ä¹‹ã€‚ ä»¥æ‰éµ²è¨€å‘Šç°¡å­ï¼Œç°¡å­è³œæ‰éµ²ç”°å››è¬ç•ã€‚
After two and a half days, Jian Zi regained consciousness. He told the grandees: 'I was very happy at the Di's place. I roamed with the hundred spirits at Jun Tian. Broad music with nine movements and ten thousand dances, not like the three dynasties' music. Its sound moves the heart. There was a bear that came to attack me. The Emperor commanded me to shoot it. I hit the bear and it died. Then another bear came. I shot it again. I hit this bear too and it died. The Emperor was greatly pleased. He granted me two baskets, each with a matching pair. I saw a child at the Di's side. The Di entrusted me with a Di dog, saying: 'When your son is strong, grant it to him.' The Di told me: 'Jin state will moreover decline through generations. It will perish in seven generations. The Ying surname will greatly defeat Zhou people west of Fan Kui, but also cannot have it. Now I think of Yu Shun's merit. Just now I will pair his descendant woman Meng Yao with your seven generations' grandson.' Dong An Yu received the words, wrote them down, and concealed them. He told Jian Zi what Bian Que had said. Jian Zi rewarded Bian Que with forty thousand mu of land.

ä»–æ—¥ï¼Œç°¡å­å‡ºï¼Œæœ‰äººç•¶é“ï¼Œè¾Ÿä¹‹ä¸å»ï¼Œå¾è€…æ€’ï¼Œå°‡åˆƒä¹‹ã€‚ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾æ¬²æœ‰è¬æ–¼ä¸»å›ã€‚ã€ å¾è€…ä»¥èã€‚ ç°¡å­å¬ä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œè­†ï¼Œå¾æœ‰æ‰€è¦‹å­æ™£ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå±å·¦å³ï¼Œé¡˜æœ‰è¬ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­å±äººã€‚ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸»å›ä¹‹ç–¾ï¼Œè‡£åœ¨å¸å´ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¶ï¼Œæœ‰ä¹‹ã€‚ å­ä¹‹è¦‹æˆ‘ï¼Œæˆ‘ä½•ç‚ºï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¸ä»¤ä¸»å›å°„ç†Šèˆ‡ç¾†ï¼Œçš†æ­»ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ˜¯ï¼Œä¸”ä½•ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ™‰åœ‹ä¸”æœ‰å¤§é›£ï¼Œä¸»å›é¦–ä¹‹ã€‚ å¸ä»¤ä¸»å›æ»…äºŒå¿ï¼Œå¤«ç†Šèˆ‡ç¾†çš†å…¶ç¥–ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¸è³œæˆ‘äºŒç¬¥çš†æœ‰å‰¯ï¼Œä½•ä¹Ÿï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸»å›ä¹‹å­å°‡å…‹äºŒåœ‹æ–¼ç¿Ÿï¼Œçš†å­å§“ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾è¦‹å…’åœ¨å¸å´ï¼Œå¸å±¬æˆ‘ä¸€ç¿ŸçŠ¬ï¼Œæ›°ã€åŠè€Œå­ä¹‹é•·ä»¥è³œä¹‹ã€ã€‚ å¤«å…’ä½•è¬‚ä»¥è³œç¿ŸçŠ¬ï¼Ÿã€ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…’ï¼Œä¸»å›ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç¿ŸçŠ¬è€…ï¼Œä»£ä¹‹å…ˆä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸»å›ä¹‹å­ä¸”å¿…æœ‰ä»£ã€‚ åŠä¸»å›ä¹‹å¾Œå—£ï¼Œä¸”æœ‰é©æ”¿è€Œèƒ¡æœï¼Œå¹¶äºŒåœ‹æ–¼ç¿Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­å•å…¶å§“è€Œå»¶ä¹‹ä»¥å®˜ã€‚ ç•¶é“è€…æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£é‡äººï¼Œè‡´å¸å‘½è€³ã€‚ã€ é‚ä¸è¦‹ã€‚ ç°¡å­æ›¸è—ä¹‹åºœã€‚
One day, Jian Zi went out. Someone blocked his path. He tried to avoid him but the man wouldn't move. His attendants grew angry and were about to attack him. The one blocking the road said: 'I desire to have an audience with the lord.' His attendants reported this to him. Jian Zi summoned him and said: 'Tai, I have seen you clearly.' The one blocking the road said: 'Dismiss the attendants on left and right. I wish to have an audience.' Jian Zi dismissed everyone else. The one blocking the road said: 'During the lord's illness, the minister was at the Di's side.' Jian Zi said: 'Yes, I had it. You saw me. What was I doing?' The one blocking the road said: 'The Di commanded the lord to shoot the bear and pi. They all died.' Jian Zi said: 'Yes. Moreover what?' The one blocking the road said: 'Jin state will moreover have great difficulty. The lord heads it. The Di commanded the lord to extinguish two ministers. Indeed the bear and pi are all their ancestors.' Jian Zi said: 'The Di granted me two baskets that all had pairs. What does this mean?' The one blocking the road said: 'The lord's son will conquer two states at Di. They are all Zi surname.' Jian Zi said: 'I saw a child at the Di's side. The Di entrusted me with a Di dog, saying 'when your son is grown, grant it to him.' Indeed, what does the child mean by granting it to the Di dog?' The one blocking the road said: 'The child is the lord's son. The Di dog is the ancestor of Dai. Your lord's son will certainly have Dai as his fief. It will reach the lord's descendants. They will moreover have changed governance and worn Hu clothing, uniting two states at Di.' Jian Zi asked his surname and offered him an official position. The one blocking the road said: 'The minister is a rustic. He only conveyed the Di's command.' He then disappeared. Jian Zi wrote it down and stored it in his treasury.

ç•°æ—¥ï¼Œå§‘å¸ƒå­å¿è¦‹ç°¡å­ï¼Œç°¡å­éå¬è«¸å­ç›¸ä¹‹ã€‚ å­å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¡ç‚ºå°‡è»è€…ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ°å…¶æ»…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å­å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å˜—è¦‹ä¸€å­æ–¼è·¯ï¼Œæ®†å›ä¹‹å­ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­å¬å­æ¯‹å¹ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹è‡³ï¼Œå‰‡å­å¿èµ·æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤çœŸå°‡è»çŸ£ï¼ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å…¶æ¯è³¤ï¼Œç¿Ÿå©¢ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¥šé“è²´å“‰ï¼Ÿã€ å­å¿æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤©æ‰€æˆï¼Œé›–è³¤å¿…è²´ã€‚ã€ è‡ªæ˜¯ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œç°¡å­ç›¡å¬è«¸å­èˆ‡èªï¼Œæ¯‹å¹æœ€è³¢ã€‚ ç°¡å­ä¹ƒå‘Šè«¸å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾è—å¯¶ç¬¦æ–¼å¸¸å±±ä¸Šï¼Œå…ˆå¾—è€…è³ã€‚ã€ è«¸å­é¦³ä¹‹å¸¸å±±ä¸Šï¼Œæ±‚ï¼Œç„¡æ‰€å¾—ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹é‚„ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå·²å¾—ç¬¦çŸ£ã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¥ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ¯‹å¹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å¸¸å±±ä¸Šè‡¨ä»£ï¼Œä»£å¯å–ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç°¡å­æ–¼æ˜¯çŸ¥æ¯‹å¹æœè³¢ï¼Œä¹ƒå»¢å¤ªå­ä¼¯é­¯ï¼Œè€Œä»¥æ¯‹å¹ç‚ºå¤ªå­ã€‚
Another day, Gu Bu Zi Qing came to see Jian Zi. Jian Zi summoned all his sons and had their physiognomy read. Zi Qing said: 'None will become generals.' Jian Zi said: 'Will the Zhao clan perhaps be extinguished?' Zi Qing said: 'I once saw a son on the road. He is perhaps the lord's son.' Jian Zi summoned his son Wu Xu. Wu Zhi arrived, then Zi Qing rose and said: 'This is the true general!' Jian Zi said: 'This one's mother is lowly, a Di concubine. How can he be noble?' Zi Qing said: 'Heaven bestowed it. Though lowly, he will certainly be noble.' From that time on, Jian Zi summoned all his sons to speak with them. Wu Xu proved the most worthy. Jian Zi then told the various sons: 'I hid a treasure tally on Chang Shan top. The first to obtain it will be rewarded.' The sons galloped to the top of Mount Chang to search for him, but found nothing. Wu Zhi returned and said: 'I have already obtained the tally.' Jian Zi said: 'Play it.' Wu Zhi said: 'From Chang Shan top, overlooking Dai, Dai can be taken.' Jian Zi then knew that Wu Xu was indeed worthy, so he deposed the crown prince Bo Lu and made Wu Xu crown prince instead.

å¾ŒäºŒå¹´ï¼Œæ™‰å®šå…¬ä¹‹åå››å¹´ï¼ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œä½œäº‚ã€‚ æ˜å¹´æ˜¥ï¼Œç°¡å­è¬‚é‚¯é„²å¤§å¤«åˆæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¸æˆ‘è¡›å£«äº”ç™¾å®¶ï¼Œå¾å°‡ç½®ä¹‹æ™‰é™½ã€‚ã€ åˆè¨±è«¾ï¼Œæ­¸è€Œå…¶çˆ¶å…„ä¸è½ï¼Œå€è¨€ã€‚ è¶™é…æ•åˆï¼Œå›šä¹‹æ™‰é™½ã€‚ ä¹ƒå‘Šé‚¯é„²äººæ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘ç§æœ‰èª…åˆä¹Ÿï¼Œè«¸å›æ¬²èª°ç«‹ï¼Ÿã€ é‚æ®ºåˆã€‚ è¶™ç¨·ã€æ¶‰è³“ä»¥é‚¯é„²åã€‚ æ™‰å›ä½¿ç±ç§¦åœé‚¯é„²ã€‚ è€å¯…ã€èŒƒå‰å°„èˆ‡åˆå–„ï¼Œä¸è‚¯åŠ©ç§¦è€Œè¬€ä½œäº‚ï¼Œè‘£å®‰äºçŸ¥ä¹‹ã€‚ åæœˆï¼ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°ä¼è¶™é…ï¼Œé…å¥”æ™‰é™½ï¼Œæ™‰äººåœä¹‹ã€‚ èŒƒå‰å°„ã€è€å¯…ä»‡äººé­è¥„ç­‰è¬€é€è€å¯…ï¼Œä»¥æ¢å¬°çˆ¶ä»£ä¹‹ï¼› é€å‰å°„ï¼Œä»¥èŒƒçš‹ç¹¹ä»£ä¹‹ã€‚ è€æ«Ÿè¨€æ–¼æ™‰ä¾¯æ›°ï¼šã€Œå›å‘½å¤§è‡£ï¼Œå§‹äº‚è€…æ­»ã€‚ ä»Šä¸‰è‡£å§‹äº‚è€Œç¨é€é…ï¼Œç”¨åˆ‘ä¸å‡ï¼Œè«‹çš†é€ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ åä¸€æœˆï¼Œè€æ«Ÿã€éŸ“ä¸ä½ã€é­å“†å¥‰å…¬å‘½ä»¥ä¼èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°ï¼Œä¸å…‹ã€‚ èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ°åä¼å…¬ï¼Œå…¬æ“Šä¹‹ï¼ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ•—èµ°ã€‚ ä¸æœªï¼ŒäºŒå­å¥”æœæ­Œã€‚ éŸ“ã€é­ä»¥è¶™æ°ç‚ºè«‹ã€‚ åäºŒæœˆè¾›æœªï¼Œè¶™é…å…¥çµ³ï¼Œç›Ÿäºå…¬å®®ã€‚ å…¶æ˜å¹´ï¼ŒçŸ¥ä¼¯æ–‡å­è¬‚è¶™é…æ›°ï¼šã€ŒèŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œé›–ä¿¡ç‚ºäº‚ï¼Œå®‰äºç™¼ä¹‹ï¼Œæ˜¯å®‰äºèˆ‡è¬€ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ™‰åœ‹æœ‰æ³•ï¼Œå§‹äº‚è€…æ­»ã€‚ å¤«äºŒå­å·²ä¼ç½ªè€Œå®‰äºç¨åœ¨ã€‚ã€ è¶™é…æ‚£ä¹‹ã€‚ å®‰äºæ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£æ­»ï¼Œè¶™æ°å®šï¼Œæ™‰åœ‹å¯§ï¼Œå¾æ­»æ™šçŸ£ã€‚ã€ é‚è‡ªæ®ºã€‚ è¶™æ°ä»¥å‘ŠçŸ¥ä¼¯ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œè¶™æ°å¯§ã€‚
Two years later, in the fourteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Fan and Zhonghang rose in rebellion. The next year in spring, Jian Zi told the Handan grandee Wu: 'Return to me five hundred households of Wei soldiers. I will place them in Jin Yang.' Wu agreed, but when he returned home his father and brothers would not listen and contradicted him. Zhao Yang captured Wu and imprisoned him in Jinyang. He then told the Handan people: 'I privately executed Wu. Whom do the various lords wish to establish?' He then executed Wu. Zhao Ji and She Bin rebelled with Handan. The lord of Jin sent Ji Qin to besiege Handan. Xun Yin and Fan Ji She were friendly with Wu. They refused to help Qin and instead plotted rebellion. Dong An Yu learned of this. In the tenth month, the Fan and Zhonghang clans attacked Zhao Yang. Yang fled to Jinyang, and the Jin people besieged him there. Fan Ji She and Xun Yin's enemies, Wei Xiang and others, plotted to expel Xun Yin and replace him with Liang Ying Fu; They drove out Ji She and replaced him with Fan Gao Xi. Xun Jue spoke to the Jin Hou: 'The lord commands that ministers who start rebellion die. Now three ministers started rebellion but only Yang is expelled. The punishment is uneven. I request all of them be expelled.' In the eleventh month, Xun Jue, Han Bu Ning, and Wei Duo, following the duke's command, attacked the Fan and Zhonghang clans but failed. The Fan and Zhonghang clans counterattacked the duke. The duke struck at them, and Fan and Zhonghang were defeated and fled. On the dingwei day, the two sons fled to Zhaoge. Han and Wei interceded on behalf of the Zhao clan. In the twelfth month on the xinwei day, Zhao Yang entered Jiang and made an alliance at the duke's palace. The next year, Zhi Bo Wen Zi told Zhao Yang: 'Although Fan and Zhonghang truly made rebellion, An Yu exposed it. This means An Yu plotted with them. Jin has a law: those who start rebellion die. Indeed the two sons have already submitted to punishment, but An Yu alone remains.' Zhao Yang was troubled by this. An Yu said: 'If the minister dies, the Zhao clan will settle and Jin state will be pacified. My death comes late.' He then took his own life. The Zhao clan informed Zhi Bo, and then the Zhao clan was pacified.

Kong Zi heard that Zhao Jian Zi executed Handan Wu without requesting the Jin lord and protected Jin Yang. Therefore he wrote in the Spring and Autumn Annals: 'Zhao Yang rebelled with Jin Yang.' Zhao Jian Zi had a minister named Zhou She who was fond of direct admonition. After Zhou She died, Jian Zi, whenever he attended court, was often displeased. The grandees begged for punishment. Jian Zi said: 'The grandees have no crime. I have heard that a thousand sheep skins do not equal one fox's armpit. The various grandees in court, I only hear wei wei agreement, not Zhou She's e e admonition. This is why I worry.' From this, Jian Zi was able to unite the Zhao cities and win over the Jin people.

In the eighteenth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Zhao Jian Zi besieged Fan and Zhonghang at Zhaoge. Zhonghang Wen Zi fled to Handan. The next year, Duke Ling of Wei died. Jian Zi and Yang Hu escorted Wei's Crown Prince Kuai Kui back to Wei. Wei refused to admit him, so he resided in Qi.

æ™‰å®šå…¬äºŒåä¸€å¹´ï¼Œç°¡å­æ‹”é‚¯é„²ï¼Œä¸­è¡Œæ–‡å­å¥”æŸäººã€‚ ç°¡å­åˆåœæŸäººï¼Œä¸­è¡Œæ–‡å­ã€èŒƒæ˜­å­é‚å¥”é½Šã€‚ è¶™ç«Ÿæœ‰é‚¯é„²ã€æŸäººã€‚ èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œé¤˜é‚‘å…¥äºæ™‰ã€‚ è¶™åæ™‰å¿ï¼Œå¯¦å°ˆæ™‰æ¬Šï¼Œå¥‰é‚‘ä¾”æ–¼è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚
In the twenty-first year of Duke Ding of Jin, Jian Zi captured Handan. Zhonghang Wen Zi fled to Bai Ren. Jian Zi again besieged Bai Ren. Zhonghang Wen Zi and Fan Zhao Zi then fled to Qi. Zhao finally possessed Handan and Bai Ren. The remaining cities of Fan and Zhonghang entered Jin. Zhao was nominally a Jin minister, but actually monopolized Jin's authority. His fief cities equaled those of feudal lords.

In the thirtieth year of Duke Ding of Jin, Ding Gong contended for precedence with King Fu Chai of Wu at Huang Chi. Zhao Jian Zi followed Jin Ding Gong and finally gave precedence to Wu. Ding Gong died in the thirty-seventh year. Jian Zi removed the three-year mourning period and made it only one year. This year, King Gou Jian of Yue extinguished Wu.

æ™‰å‡ºå…¬åä¸€å¹´ï¼ŒçŸ¥ä¼¯ä¼é„­ã€‚ è¶™ç°¡å­ç–¾ï¼Œä½¿å¤ªå­æ¯‹å¹å°‡è€Œåœé„­ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯é†‰ï¼Œä»¥é…’çŒæ“Šæ¯‹å¹ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹ç¾¤è‡£è«‹æ­»ä¹‹ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå›æ‰€ä»¥ç½®æ¯‹å¹ï¼Œç‚ºèƒ½å¿ã€‚ã€ ç„¶äº¦æ…çŸ¥ä¼¯ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯æ­¸ï¼Œå› è¬‚ç°¡å­ï¼Œä½¿å»¢æ¯‹å¹ï¼Œç°¡å­ä¸è½ã€‚ æ¯‹å¹ç”±æ­¤æ€¨çŸ¥ä¼¯ã€‚
In the eleventh year of Duke Chu of Jin, Zhi Bo attacked Zheng. Zhao Jian Zi was ill and sent Crown Prince Wu Zhi to lead the army and surround Zheng. Zhi Bo was drunk and poured wine while striking Wu Zhi. Wu Zhi's group of ministers requested to die for him. Wu Zhi said: 'The reason the lord placed Wu Zhi was for his ability to endure.' Yet he also resented Zhi Bo. Zhi Bo returned and then told Jian Zi to depose Wu Zhi. Jian Zi did not listen. Wu Zhi from this resented Zhi Bo.

In the seventeenth year of Duke Chu of Jin, Jian Zi died. Crown Prince Wu Zhi succeeded and was established. This was Xiang Zi.

In Zhao Xiang Zi's first year, Yue surrounded Wu. Xiang Zi reduced his mourning food and sent Chu Long to inquire about the Wu Wang.

è¥„å­å§Šå‰ç‚ºä»£ç‹å¤«äººã€‚ ç°¡å­æ—¢è‘¬ï¼Œæœªé™¤æœï¼ŒåŒ—ç™»å¤å±‹ï¼Œè«‹ä»£ç‹ã€‚ ä½¿å»šäººæ“éŠ…æ“ä»¥é£Ÿä»£ç‹åŠå¾è€…ï¼Œè¡Œæ–Ÿï¼Œé™°ä»¤å®°äººå„ä»¥æ“æ“Šæ®ºä»£ç‹åŠå¾å®˜ï¼Œé‚èˆˆå…µå¹³ä»£åœ°ã€‚ å…¶å§Šèä¹‹ï¼Œæ³£è€Œå‘¼å¤©ï¼Œæ‘©ç¬„è‡ªæ®ºã€‚ ä»£äººæ†ä¹‹ï¼Œæ‰€æ­»åœ°åä¹‹ç‚ºæ‘©ç¬„ä¹‹å±±ã€‚ é‚ä»¥ä»£å°ä¼¯é­¯å­å‘¨ç‚ºä»£æˆå›ã€‚ ä¼¯é­¯è€…ï¼Œè¥„å­å…„ï¼Œæ•…å¤ªå­ã€‚ å¤ªå­èš¤æ­»ï¼Œæ•…å°å…¶å­ã€‚
Xiang Zi's elder sister had previously been the wife of the Dai Wang. After Jian Zi was buried but before mourning garments were removed, he ascended Xia Wu in the north and invited the Dai Wang. He sent cooks holding bronze dou vessels to feed the Dai Wang and his followers. As they went pouring wine, he secretly commanded the cooks to each strike and kill the Dai Wang and his following officials with the dou vessels. He then raised troops and pacified the Dai lands. His elder sister heard it, wept while calling to heaven, rubbed her hairpin, and committed suicide. The Dai people pitied her. The place where she died was named Mo Ji Mountain. He then enfeoffed Bo Lu's son Zhou with Dai as Dai Cheng Jun. Bo Lu was Xiang Zi's elder brother and former crown prince. The crown prince died early, therefore he enfeoffed his son.

è¥„å­ç«‹å››å¹´ï¼ŒçŸ¥ä¼¯èˆ‡è¶™ã€éŸ“ã€é­ç›¡åˆ†å…¶èŒƒã€ä¸­è¡Œæ•…åœ°ã€‚ æ™‰å‡ºå…¬æ€’ï¼Œå‘Šé½Šã€é­¯ï¼Œæ¬²ä»¥ä¼å››å¿ã€‚ å››å¿æï¼Œé‚å…±æ”»å‡ºå…¬ã€‚ å‡ºå…¬å¥”é½Šï¼Œé“æ­»ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯ä¹ƒç«‹æ˜­å…¬æ›¾å­«é©•ï¼Œæ˜¯ç‚ºæ™‰æ‡¿å…¬ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯ç›Šé©•ã€‚ è«‹åœ°éŸ“ã€é­ï¼ŒéŸ“ã€é­èˆ‡ä¹‹ã€‚ è«‹åœ°è¶™ï¼Œè¶™ä¸èˆ‡ï¼Œä»¥å…¶åœé„­ä¹‹è¾±ã€‚ çŸ¥ä¼¯æ€’ï¼Œé‚ç‡éŸ“ã€é­æ”»è¶™ã€‚ è¶™è¥„å­æ‡¼ï¼Œä¹ƒå¥”ä¿æ™‰é™½ã€‚
In Xiang Zi's fourth year of establishment, Zhi Bo with Zhao, Han, and Wei completely divided the former lands of Fan and Zhonghang. Jin Chu Gong was angered and informed Qi and Lu, wishing to attack the four ministers. The four ministers feared and then together attacked Chu Gong. Chu Gong fled to Qi and died on the road. Zhi Bo then established Zhao Gong's great-grandson Jiao. This was Jin Yi Gong. Zhi Bo became moreover arrogant. He requested land from Han and Wei. Han and Wei gave it. He requested land from Zhao. Zhao did not give it, because of the humiliation at the surrounding of Zheng. Zhi Bo was angered and then led Han and Wei to attack Zhao. Zhao Xiang Zi feared and then fled to defend Jin Yang.

åŸéå¾ï¼Œå¾Œï¼Œè‡³æ–¼ç‹æ¾¤ï¼Œè¦‹ä¸‰äººï¼Œè‡ªå¸¶ä»¥ä¸Šå¯è¦‹ï¼Œè‡ªå¸¶ä»¥ä¸‹ä¸å¯è¦‹ã€‚ èˆ‡åŸéç«¹äºŒç¯€ï¼Œè«é€šã€‚ æ›°ï¼šã€Œç‚ºæˆ‘ä»¥æ˜¯éºè¶™æ¯‹å¹ã€‚ã€ åŸéæ—¢è‡³ï¼Œä»¥å‘Šè¥„å­ã€‚ è¥„å­é½Šä¸‰æ—¥ï¼Œè¦ªè‡ªå‰–ç«¹ï¼Œæœ‰æœ±æ›¸æ›°ï¼šã€Œè¶™æ¯‹å¹ï¼Œä½™éœæ³°å±±å±±é™½ä¾¯å¤©ä½¿ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸‰æœˆä¸™æˆŒï¼Œä½™å°‡ä½¿å¥³åæ»…çŸ¥æ°ã€‚ å¥³äº¦ç«‹æˆ‘ç™¾é‚‘ï¼Œä½™å°‡è³œå¥³æ—èƒ¡ä¹‹åœ°ã€‚ è‡³äºå¾Œä¸–ï¼Œä¸”æœ‰ä¼‰ç‹ï¼Œèµ¤é»‘ï¼Œé¾é¢è€Œé³¥å™£ï¼Œé¬¢éº‹é«­é«¯ï¼Œå¤§è†ºå¤§èƒ¸ï¼Œä¿®ä¸‹è€Œé¦®ï¼Œå·¦è¢µç•Œä¹˜ï¼Œå¥„æœ‰æ²³å®—ï¼Œè‡³äºä¼‘æº·è«¸è²‰ï¼Œå—ä¼æ™‰åˆ¥ï¼ŒåŒ—æ»…é»‘å§‘ã€‚ã€ è¥„å­å†æ‹œï¼Œå—ä¸‰ç¥ä¹‹ä»¤ã€‚
Yuan Guo followed afterwards. He reached Wang Ze and saw three people. From the belt above they were visible, from the belt below they were invisible. He gave Yuan Guo two sections of bamboo, not opened. He said: 'For me, leave this to Zhao Wu Zhi.' When Yuan Guo arrived, he told Xiang Zi. Xiang Zi fasted for three days and personally split the bamboo. It had vermilion writing that said: 'Zhao Wu Zhi, I am the heavenly envoy of Huo Tai Shan Shan Yang Hou. On the Bing Xu of the third month, I will make you counter and extinguish the Zhi clan. You also establish a hundred cities for me. I will grant you the lands of Lin Hu. It will reach later generations. There will moreover be a strong king, red and black, dragon face with bird beak, deer hair whiskers and beard, big chest big breast, long below and supporting, left collar boundary riding, encompassing the He Zong, reaching the various Hu of Xiu Hun, south attacking Jin's separation, north extinguishing Hei Gu.' Xiang Zi bowed twice and received the three spirits' command.

The three states attacked Jin Yang. After more than a year, they led Fen water to flood the city. The city was not submerged by three boards. In the city, they suspended cauldrons to cook and exchanged children to eat. The group of ministers all had outside hearts. Rites became moreover slow. Only Gao Gong dared not lose rites. Xiang Zi feared and then at night sent the minister Zhang Meng Tong privately to Han and Wei. Han and Wei joined in the plot. On the Bing Xu of the third month, the three states counter-attacked and extinguished the Zhi clan, together dividing its lands. Thereupon Xiang Zi gave rewards. Gao Gong was the highest. Zhang Meng Tong said: 'In the Jin Yang difficulty, only Gong had no merit.' Xiang Zi said: 'When Jin Yang was urgent, the group of ministers were all slack. Only Gong dared not lose minister rites. Therefore he is first.' Thereupon Zhao had Dai in the north and annexed the Zhi clan in the south. It was strong compared to Han and Wei. He then sacrificed to the three spirits at a hundred cities and sent Yuan Guo to preside over the Huo Tai Shan sacrifice rites.

Lie Hou liked music. He told the chancellor Gong Zhong Lian: 'I have a love. Can I ennoble it?' Gong Zhong said: 'You can enrich it, but ennobling it is not appropriate.' Lie Hou said: 'Yes. Indeed the Zheng singers Qiang and Shi, two people. I will grant them fields, each ten thousand mu.' Gong Zhong said: 'Yes.' He did not give. After one month, Lie Hou came from Dai and asked about the singers' fields. Gong Zhong said: 'Seeking them, not yet have suitable ones.' After a moment, Lie Hou asked again. Gong Zhong finally did not give. He then claimed illness and did not attend court. Fan Wu Jun came from Dai and told Gong Zhong: 'You indeed love goodness, but do not know what to hold. Now Gong Zhong has been chancellor of Zhao for four years. Have you also advanced any scholars?' Gong Zhong said: 'Not yet.' Fan Wu Jun said: 'Niu Xu, Xun Xin, Xu Yue are all suitable.' Gong Zhong then advanced the three people. At court, Lie Hou again asked: 'How are the singers' fields?' Gong Zhong said: 'I just sent people to choose good ones for them.' Niu Xu served Lie Hou with benevolence and righteousness, restrained him with the way of the king. Lie Hou became enlightened. The next day, Xun Xin served, with selecting and training to raise the worthy, appointing officials and employing the able. The next day, Xu Yue served, with restraining wealth and frugal use, examining and measuring merit and virtue. What was given was nothing but full. The lord was pleased. Lie Hou sent an envoy to tell the chancellor: 'The singers' fields should moreover stop.' He appointed Niu Xu as teacher, Xun Xin as central captain, Xu Yue as inner scribe, and granted the chancellor two sets of clothes.

å…«å¹´ï¼ŒéŸ“æ“Šç§¦ï¼Œä¸å‹è€Œå»ã€‚ äº”åœ‹ç›¸ç‹ï¼Œè¶™ç¨å¦ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¡å…¶å¯¦ï¼Œæ•¢è™•å…¶åä¹ï¼ã€ ä»¤åœ‹äººè¬‚å·²æ›°ã€Œå›ã€ã€‚
In the eighth year, Han attacked Qin but was not victorious and departed. The five states mutually became kings. Zhao alone did not, saying: 'Without its substance, how dare I occupy its name!' He commanded the state people to call him 'Jun'.

ä¹å¹´ï¼Œèˆ‡éŸ“ã€é­å…±æ“Šç§¦ï¼Œç§¦æ•—æˆ‘ï¼Œæ–¬é¦–å…«è¬ç´šã€‚ é½Šæ•—æˆ‘è§€æ¾¤ã€‚ åå¹´ï¼Œç§¦å–æˆ‘ä¸­éƒ½åŠè¥¿é™½ã€‚ é½Šç ´ç‡•ã€‚ ç‡•ç›¸å­ä¹‹ç‚ºå›ï¼Œå›åç‚ºè‡£ã€‚ åä¸€å¹´ï¼Œç‹å¬å…¬å­è·æ–¼éŸ“ï¼Œç«‹ä»¥ç‚ºç‡•ç‹ï¼Œä½¿æ¨‚æ± é€ä¹‹ã€‚ åä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œç§¦æ‹”æˆ‘è—ºï¼Œè™œå°‡è»è¶™èŠã€‚ æ¥šã€é­ç‹ä¾†ï¼Œéé‚¯é„²ã€‚ åå››å¹´ï¼Œè¶™ä½•æ”»é­ã€‚
In the ninth year, with Han and Wei they together attacked Qin. Qin defeated us and beheaded eighty thousand. Qi defeated our Guan Ze. In the tenth year, Qin took our Zhong Du and Xi Yang. Qi broke Yan. Yan's chancellor Zi Zhi became lord, and the lord instead became minister. In the eleventh year, the Wang summoned Prince Zhi from Han and established him as Yan Wang, sending Yue Chi to deliver him. In the thirteenth year, Qin captured our Lin and captured General Zhao Zhuang. The Chu and Wei Wang came and passed through Handan. In the fourteenth year, Zhao He attacked Wei.

In the sixteenth year, Qin Hui Wang died. The Wang toured Da Ling. Another day, the Wang dreamed he saw a maiden strumming a zither and singing a poem that said: 'Beautiful person shining, countenance like tiao in glory. Fate, oh fate, ever without my Ying!' Another day, the Wang drank wine and was happy. He repeatedly spoke of what he dreamed and imagined seeing her appearance. Wu Guang heard it and, through the wife, brought in his daughter Wa Ying. She was Meng Yao. Meng Yao was very favored by the Wang. She became Hui Hou.

In the seventeenth year, the Wang went out the nine gates and made a wild terrace to overlook the borders of Qi and Zhongshan.

In the eighteenth year, Qin Wu Wang with Meng Yue lifted the dragon-patterned red ding and broke his kneecap and died. Zhao Wang sent Dai chancellor Zhao Gu to welcome Prince Ji from Yan, sent him back, and established him as Qin Wang. This was Zhao Wang.

åä¹å¹´æ˜¥æ­£æœˆï¼Œå¤§æœä¿¡å®®ã€‚ å¬è‚¥ç¾©èˆ‡è­°å¤©ä¸‹ï¼Œäº”æ—¥è€Œç•¢ã€‚ ç‹åŒ—ç•¥ä¸­å±±ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œè‡³æ–¼æˆ¿å­ï¼Œé‚ä¹‹ä»£ï¼ŒåŒ—è‡³ç„¡çª®ï¼Œè¥¿è‡³æ²³ï¼Œç™»é»ƒè¯ä¹‹ä¸Šã€‚ å¬æ¨“ç·©è¬€æ›°ï¼šã€Œæˆ‘å…ˆç‹å› ä¸–ä¹‹è®Šï¼Œä»¥é•·å—è—©ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå±¬é˜»æ¼³ã€æ»ä¹‹éšªï¼Œç«‹é•·åŸï¼Œåˆå–è—ºã€éƒ­ç‹¼ï¼Œæ•—æ—äººæ–¼èï¼Œè€ŒåŠŸæœªé‚ã€‚ ä»Šä¸­å±±åœ¨æˆ‘è…¹å¿ƒï¼ŒåŒ—æœ‰ç‡•ï¼Œæ±æœ‰èƒ¡ï¼Œè¥¿æœ‰æ—èƒ¡ã€æ¨“ç…©ã€ç§¦ã€éŸ“ä¹‹é‚Šï¼Œè€Œç„¡å½Šå…µä¹‹æ•‘ï¼Œæ˜¯äº¡ç¤¾ç¨·ï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿ å¤«æœ‰é«˜ä¸–ä¹‹åï¼Œå¿…æœ‰éºä¿—ä¹‹ç´¯ã€‚ å¾æ¬²èƒ¡æœã€‚ã€ æ¨“ç·©æ›°ï¼šã€Œå–„ã€‚ã€ ç¾¤è‡£çš†ä¸æ¬²ã€‚
In the nineteenth year, spring, first month, great court at Xin Gong. He summoned Fei Yi to discuss the world with him. They finished in five days. The Wang raided Zhongshan's lands to the north, reaching Fang Zi, then Dai, north to the endless, west to the river, and ascended above Huang Hua. He summoned Lou Huan to plot, saying: 'My former king followed the world's changes to extend the southern border lands. He attached and blocked the dangers of Zhang and Fu, established a long wall, moreover took Lin and Guo Lang, defeated the Lin people at Ren, but the merit was not completed. Now Zhongshan is in my abdomen and heart. North has Yan, east has Hu, west has the borders of Lin Hu, Lou Fan, Qin, and Han, but no strong troops for rescue. This will perish the state altars. How to deal with it? Indeed, having a high world name certainly brings the burden of transcending custom. I desire Hu clothing.' Lou Huan said: 'Good.' All the group ministers did not desire it.

æ–¼æ˜¯è‚¥ç¾©ä¾ï¼Œç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œç°¡ã€è¥„ä¸»ä¹‹çƒˆï¼Œè¨ˆèƒ¡ã€ç¿Ÿä¹‹åˆ©ã€‚ ç‚ºäººè‡£è€…ï¼Œå¯µæœ‰å­å¼Ÿé•·å¹¼é †æ˜ä¹‹ç¯€ï¼Œé€šæœ‰è£œæ°‘ç›Šä¸»ä¹‹æ¥­ï¼Œæ­¤å…©è€…è‡£ä¹‹åˆ†ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šå¾æ¬²ç¹¼è¥„ä¸»ä¹‹è·¡ï¼Œé–‹æ–¼èƒ¡ã€ç¿Ÿä¹‹é„‰ï¼Œè€Œå’ä¸–ä¸è¦‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç‚ºæ•µå¼±ï¼Œç”¨åŠ›å°‘è€ŒåŠŸå¤šï¼Œå¯ä»¥æ¯‹ç›¡ç™¾å§“ä¹‹å‹ï¼Œè€Œåºå¾€å¤ä¹‹å‹³ã€‚ å¤«æœ‰é«˜ä¸–ä¹‹åŠŸè€…ï¼Œè² éºä¿—ä¹‹ç´¯ï¼› æœ‰ç¨æ™ºä¹‹æ…®è€…ï¼Œä»»é©æ°‘ä¹‹æ€¨ã€‚ ä»Šå¾å°‡èƒ¡æœé¨å°„ä»¥æ•™ç™¾å§“ï¼Œè€Œä¸–å¿…è­°å¯¡äººï¼ŒæŸ°ä½•ï¼Ÿã€ è‚¥ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£èç–‘äº‹ç„¡åŠŸï¼Œç–‘è¡Œç„¡åã€‚ ç‹æ—¢å®šè² éºä¿—ä¹‹æ…®ï¼Œæ®†ç„¡é¡§å¤©ä¸‹ä¹‹è­°çŸ£ã€‚ å¤«è«–è‡³å¾·è€…ä¸å’Œæ–¼ä¿—ï¼Œæˆå¤§åŠŸè€…ä¸è¬€æ–¼çœ¾ã€‚ æ˜”è€…èˆœèˆæœ‰è‹—ï¼Œç¦¹è¢’è£¸åœ‹ï¼Œéä»¥é¤Šæ¬²è€Œæ¨‚å¿—ä¹Ÿï¼Œå‹™ä»¥è«–å¾·è€Œç´„åŠŸä¹Ÿã€‚ æ„šè€…é—‡æˆäº‹ï¼Œæ™ºè€…ç¹æœªå½¢ï¼Œå‰‡ç‹ä½•ç–‘ç„‰ã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾ä¸ç–‘èƒ¡æœä¹Ÿï¼Œå¾æå¤©ä¸‹ç¬‘æˆ‘ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç‹‚å¤«ä¹‹æ¨‚ï¼Œæ™ºè€…å“€ç„‰ï¼› æ„šè€…æ‰€ç¬‘ï¼Œè³¢è€…å¯Ÿç„‰ã€‚ ä¸–æœ‰é †æˆ‘è€…ï¼Œèƒ¡æœä¹‹åŠŸæœªå¯çŸ¥ä¹Ÿã€‚ é›–é©…ä¸–ä»¥ç¬‘æˆ‘ï¼Œèƒ¡åœ°ä¸­å±±å¾å¿…æœ‰ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯é‚èƒ¡æœçŸ£ã€‚
Thereupon Fei Yi served. The Wang said: 'Jian and Xiang lord were vigorous. They calculated the benefits of Hu and Di. Being a minister, favor has the sections of filial piety, respect for elders, orderly relationships, and clarity. Comprehensive has enterprises that supplement the people and benefit the lord. These two are the minister's duty. Now I desire to continue Xiang lord's tracks, open to the regions of Hu and Di, but the lifetime world does not see it. Make the enemy weak, use little strength but gain much merit, can avoid exhausting the commoners' labor, and arrange the merits of past ancients. Indeed, those with high world merit bear the burden of transcending custom; Those with unique wisdom considerations bear the resentment of stubborn people. Now I will teach the commoners Hu clothing and riding with shooting, but the world will certainly criticize me. How to deal with it?' Fei Yi said: 'The minister has heard that doubtful affairs bring no merit, doubtful conduct brings no name. The Wang had already decided to bear the considerations of transcending custom. He almost had no regard for the world's discussions. Indeed, those who discuss supreme virtue do not harmonize with custom. Those who complete great merit do not consult with the multitude. Formerly, Shun danced for the You Miao, Yu bared himself in naked states. It was not to nourish desires and please their wills, but devoted to discussing virtue and restraining merit. The foolish are in the dark about completing affairs. The wise see what is not yet formed. So why should the Wang doubt?' The Wang said: 'I do not doubt Hu clothing. I fear the world will laugh at me. The madman's pleasure is mourned by the wise; What the foolish laugh at is examined by the worthy. If the world has those who follow me, the merit of Hu clothing cannot yet be known. Though I drive the world to laugh at me, I will certainly have the Hu lands and Zhongshan.' Thereupon he then adopted Hu clothing.

ä½¿ç‹ç´²å…¬å­æˆæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¯¡äººèƒ¡æœï¼Œå°‡ä»¥æœä¹Ÿï¼Œäº¦æ¬²å”æœä¹‹ã€‚ å®¶è½æ–¼è¦ªè€Œåœ‹è½æ–¼å›ï¼Œå¤ä»Šä¹‹å…¬è¡Œä¹Ÿã€‚ å­ä¸åè¦ªï¼Œè‡£ä¸é€†å›ï¼Œå…„å¼Ÿä¹‹é€šç¾©ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šå¯¡äººä½œæ•™æ˜“æœè€Œå”ä¸æœï¼Œå¾æå¤©ä¸‹è­°ä¹‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ åˆ¶åœ‹æœ‰å¸¸ï¼Œåˆ©æ°‘ç‚ºæœ¬ï¼› å¾æ”¿æœ‰ç¶“ï¼Œä»¤è¡Œç‚ºä¸Šã€‚ æ˜å¾·å…ˆè«–æ–¼è³¤ï¼Œè€Œè¡Œæ”¿å…ˆä¿¡æ–¼è²´ã€‚ ä»Šèƒ¡æœä¹‹æ„ï¼Œéä»¥é¤Šæ¬²è€Œæ¨‚å¿—ä¹Ÿï¼› äº‹æœ‰æ‰€æ­¢è€ŒåŠŸæœ‰æ‰€å‡ºï¼Œäº‹æˆåŠŸç«‹ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œå–„ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šå¯¡äººæå”ä¹‹é€†å¾æ”¿ä¹‹ç¶“ï¼Œä»¥è¼”å”ä¹‹è­°ã€‚ ä¸”å¯¡äººèä¹‹ï¼Œäº‹åˆ©åœ‹è€…è¡Œç„¡é‚ªï¼Œå› è²´æˆšè€…åä¸ç´¯ï¼Œæ•…é¡˜æ…•å…¬å”ä¹‹ç¾©ï¼Œä»¥æˆèƒ¡æœä¹‹åŠŸã€‚ ä½¿ç´²è¬ä¹‹å”ï¼Œè«‹æœç„‰ã€‚ã€ å…¬å­æˆå†æ‹œç¨½é¦–æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£å›ºèç‹ä¹‹èƒ¡æœä¹Ÿã€‚ è‡£ä¸ä½ï¼Œå¯¢ç–¾ï¼Œæœªèƒ½è¶¨èµ°ä»¥æ»‹é€²ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç‹å‘½ä¹‹ï¼Œè‡£æ•¢å°ï¼Œå› ç«­å…¶æ„šå¿ ã€‚ æ›°ï¼šè‡£èä¸­åœ‹è€…ï¼Œè“‹è°æ˜å¾‡æ™ºä¹‹æ‰€å±…ä¹Ÿï¼Œè¬ç‰©è²¡ç”¨ä¹‹æ‰€èšä¹Ÿï¼Œè³¢è–ä¹‹æ‰€æ•™ä¹Ÿï¼Œä»ç¾©ä¹‹æ‰€æ–½ä¹Ÿï¼Œè©©æ›¸ç¦®æ¨‚ä¹‹æ‰€ç”¨ä¹Ÿï¼Œç•°æ•æŠ€èƒ½ä¹‹æ‰€è©¦ä¹Ÿï¼Œé æ–¹ä¹‹æ‰€è§€èµ´ä¹Ÿï¼Œè »å¤·ä¹‹æ‰€ç¾©è¡Œä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šç‹æ¨æ­¤è€Œè¥²é æ–¹ä¹‹æœï¼Œè®Šå¤ä¹‹æ•™ï¼Œæ˜“å¤äººé“ï¼Œé€†äººä¹‹å¿ƒï¼Œè€Œæ€«å­¸è€…ï¼Œé›¢ä¸­åœ‹ï¼Œæ•…è‡£é¡˜ç‹åœ–ä¹‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ä½¿è€…ä»¥å ±ã€‚ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾å›ºèå”ä¹‹ç–¾ä¹Ÿï¼Œæˆ‘å°‡è‡ªå¾€è«‹ä¹‹ã€‚ã€
He sent Wang Xi to Prince Cheng, saying: 'I have adopted Hu clothing, which will be for court. I also desire that uncle wear it. The family listens to parents and the country listens to the lord. This is the public practice of ancient and modern times. Sons do not oppose parents, ministers do not defy lords. This is the common righteousness of brothers. Now I establish teaching and change clothing, but if uncle does not wear it, I fear the world will discuss it. Governing the state has constants, with benefiting the people as foundation; Following governance has the warp, with commands and conduct above. Bright virtue is first discussed with the lowly, but administering government first trusts with the noble. Now the intent of Hu clothing is not to nourish desires and please the will; Affairs have a stopping place and merit has a coming out. When affairs succeed and are established, then it is good. Now I fear uncle will oppose following the governance warp, to supplement uncle's discussions. Moreover I have heard that affairs which benefit the state have conduct without evil, relying on noble relatives brings name without burden. Therefore I wish to admire Gong Shu's righteousness to complete the merit of Hu clothing. I sent Xi to have an audience with uncle and request that he wear it.' Prince Cheng bowed twice and knocked his head, saying: 'The minister has certainly heard of the Wang's Hu clothing. The minister is not worthy. I have bed illness and am not able to hasten and walk to increase advancement. The Wang commands it. The minister dares to respond and thus exhausts his stupid loyalty. He said: The minister has heard that Zhongguo is where clever intelligence and following wisdom reside, where the wealth and use of ten thousand things gather, where worthy sages teach, where benevolence and righteousness are applied, where poetry, books, rites, and music are used, where different clever skills are tried, where distant places observe and hasten to, where Man and Yi conduct righteousness. Now the Wang abandons this and attacks the clothing of distant places, changes ancient teachings, alters the ancient people's way, opposes people's hearts, angers scholars, separates Zhongguo. Therefore the minister wishes the Wang to plan it.' The envoy reported it. The Wang said: 'I have certainly heard of uncle's illness. I will personally go and request it.'

ç‹é‚å¾€ä¹‹å…¬å­æˆå®¶ï¼Œå› è‡ªè«‹ä¹‹ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤«æœè€…ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¾¿ç”¨ä¹Ÿï¼› ç¦®è€…ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¾¿äº‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ è–äººè§€é„‰è€Œé †å®œï¼Œå› äº‹è€Œåˆ¶ç¦®ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åˆ©å…¶æ°‘è€Œåšå…¶åœ‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¤«ç¿¦ç™¼æ–‡èº«ï¼ŒéŒ¯è‡‚å·¦è¡½ï¼Œç”Œè¶Šä¹‹æ°‘ä¹Ÿã€‚ é»‘é½’é›•é¡Œï¼Œå»å† ç§«çµ€ï¼Œå¤§å³ä¹‹åœ‹ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ•…ç¦®æœè«åŒï¼Œå…¶ä¾¿ä¸€ä¹Ÿã€‚ é„‰ç•°è€Œç”¨è®Šï¼Œäº‹ç•°è€Œç¦®æ˜“ã€‚ æ˜¯ä»¥è–äººæœå¯ä»¥åˆ©å…¶åœ‹ï¼Œä¸ä¸€å…¶ç”¨ï¼› æœå¯ä»¥ä¾¿å…¶äº‹ï¼Œä¸åŒå…¶ç¦®ã€‚ å„’è€…ä¸€å¸«è€Œä¿—ç•°ï¼Œä¸­åœ‹åŒç¦®è€Œæ•™é›¢ï¼Œæ³æ–¼å±±è°·ä¹‹ä¾¿ä¹ï¼Ÿ æ•…å»å°±ä¹‹è®Šï¼Œæ™ºè€…ä¸èƒ½ä¸€ï¼› é è¿‘ä¹‹æœï¼Œè³¢è–ä¸èƒ½åŒã€‚ çª®é„‰å¤šç•°ï¼Œæ›²å­¸å¤šè¾¯ã€‚ ä¸çŸ¥è€Œä¸ç–‘ï¼Œç•°æ–¼å·±è€Œä¸éè€…ï¼Œå…¬ç„‰è€Œçœ¾æ±‚ç›¡å–„ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šå”ä¹‹æ‰€è¨€è€…ä¿—ä¹Ÿï¼Œå¾æ‰€è¨€è€…æ‰€ä»¥åˆ¶ä¿—ä¹Ÿã€‚ å¾åœ‹æ±æœ‰æ²³ã€è–„æ´›ä¹‹æ°´ï¼Œèˆ‡é½Šã€ä¸­å±±åŒä¹‹ï¼Œç„¡èˆŸæ¥«ä¹‹ç”¨ã€‚ è‡ªå¸¸å±±ä»¥è‡³ä»£ã€ä¸Šé»¨ï¼Œæ±æœ‰ç‡•ã€æ±èƒ¡ä¹‹å¢ƒï¼Œè€Œè¥¿æœ‰æ¨“ç…©ã€ç§¦ã€éŸ“ä¹‹é‚Šï¼Œä»Šç„¡é¨å°„ä¹‹å‚™ã€‚ æ•…å¯¡äººç„¡èˆŸæ¥«ä¹‹ç”¨ï¼Œå¤¾æ°´å±…ä¹‹æ°‘ï¼Œå°‡ä½•ä»¥å®ˆæ²³ã€è–„æ´›ä¹‹æ°´ï¼› è®Šæœé¨å°„ï¼Œä»¥å‚™ç‡•ã€ä¸‰èƒ¡ã€ç§¦ã€éŸ“ä¹‹é‚Šã€‚ ä¸”æ˜”è€…ç°¡ä¸»ä¸å¡æ™‰é™½ä»¥åŠä¸Šé»¨ï¼Œè€Œè¥„ä¸»å¹¶æˆå–ä»£ä»¥æ”˜è«¸èƒ¡ï¼Œæ­¤æ„šæ™ºæ‰€æ˜ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…ˆæ™‚ä¸­å±±è² é½Šä¹‹å½Šå…µï¼Œä¾µæš´å¾åœ°ï¼Œç³»ç´¯å¾æ°‘ï¼Œå¼•æ°´åœé„—ï¼Œå¾®ç¤¾ç¨·ä¹‹ç¥éˆï¼Œå‰‡é„—å¹¾æ–¼ä¸å®ˆä¹Ÿã€‚ å…ˆç‹ä¸‘ä¹‹ï¼Œè€Œæ€¨æœªèƒ½å ±ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šé¨å°„ä¹‹å‚™ï¼Œè¿‘å¯ä»¥ä¾¿ä¸Šé»¨ä¹‹å½¢ï¼Œè€Œé å¯ä»¥å ±ä¸­å±±ä¹‹æ€¨ã€‚ è€Œå”é †ä¸­åœ‹ä¹‹ä¿—ä»¥é€†ç°¡ã€è¥„ä¹‹æ„ï¼Œæƒ¡è®Šæœä¹‹åä»¥å¿˜é„—äº‹ä¹‹ä¸‘ï¼Œéå¯¡äººä¹‹æ‰€æœ›ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å…¬å­—æˆå†æ‹œç¨½é¦–æ›°ï¼šã€Œè‡£æ„šï¼Œä¸é”æ–¼ç‹ä¹‹ç¾©ï¼Œæ•¢é“ä¸–ä¿—ä¹‹èï¼Œè‡£ä¹‹ç½ªä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šç‹å°‡ç¹¼ç°¡ã€è¥„ä¹‹æ„ä»¥é †å…ˆç‹ä¹‹å¿—ï¼Œè‡£æ•¢ä¸è½å‘½ä¹ï¼ã€ å†æ‹œç¨½é¦–ã€‚ ä¹ƒè³œèƒ¡æœã€‚ æ˜æ—¥ï¼Œæœè€Œæœã€‚ æ–¼æ˜¯å§‹å‡ºèƒ¡æœä»¤ä¹Ÿã€‚
The Wang then went to Prince Cheng's home and thus personally requested it, saying: 'Indeed clothing is what makes use convenient; Rites are what make affairs convenient. Sages observe regions and follow what is suitable, rely on affairs and create rites, which benefits their people and thickens their country. Indeed, cutting hair and tattooing the body, tattooing the arm with left collar - these are Ou Yue people. Black teeth and carving the forehead, retreating the crown with grain shoes - this is Da Wu country. Therefore rites and clothing are not the same, but their convenience is one. Regions differ and use changes. Affairs differ and rites alter. This is why sages, if they can benefit their country, do not unify their use; If they can make affairs convenient, they do not make rites the same. The Ru have one teacher but customs differ. Zhongguo has the same rites but teachings separate. How much more so for mountain and valley convenience? Therefore, depart and approach changes - even the wise cannot unify them; Distant and close clothing - even worthy sages cannot make them the same. Poor regions have many differences. Crooked learning has many arguments. Those who do not know but do not doubt, who are different from oneself but do not criticize - they are public and the crowd seeks complete goodness. Now what uncle said is custom. What I said is to control custom. My country's east has the waters of He and Bo Luo, the same as Qi and Zhongshan. There is no use for boats and oars. From Chang Shan to Dai and Shang Dang, the east has the borders of Yan and Dong Hu, while the west has the borders of Lou Fan, Qin, and Han. Now there are no preparations for riding and shooting. Therefore I have no use for boats and oars. The people who dwell flanked by water will use what to guard the waters of He and Bo Luo; Change clothing to riding and shooting to prepare for the borders of Yan, the three Hu, Qin, and Han. Moreover, in former times Jian lord did not block Jin Yang from reaching Shang Dang, while Xiang lord annexed the Rong and replaced Dai to drive away the various Hu. This is what both foolish and wise understand. In former times, Zhongshan relied on Qi's strong troops, invaded and bullied my lands, bound and burdened my people, led water to surround Hao. Without the spirits of the state altars, Hao would nearly not have been defended. The former king was shamed by it, and the resentment has not yet been repaid. Now preparations for riding and shooting can, nearby, make Shang Dang's situation convenient, and far away, repay Zhongshan's resentment. But uncle follows Zhongguo's custom to oppose Jian and Xiang's intent, hates the name of changing clothing to forget the shame of the Hao affair. This is not what I hope for.' Gong Zi Cheng bowed twice and knocked his head, saying: 'The minister is foolish and does not reach the Wang's righteousness. He dares to speak of what the world custom hears. This is the minister's crime. Now the Wang will continue Jian and Xiang's intent to follow the former king's will. How dare the minister not listen to the command!' He bowed twice and knocked his head. He then granted Hu clothing. The next day, he wore the clothing and attended court. Thereupon he began to issue the Hu clothing command.
68
è¶™æ–‡ã€è¶™é€ ã€å‘¨è¢‘ã€è¶™ä¿Šçš†è««æ­¢ç‹æ¯‹èƒ¡æœï¼Œå¦‚æ•…æ³•ä¾¿ã€‚ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…ˆç‹ä¸åŒä¿—ï¼Œä½•å¤ä¹‹æ³•ï¼Ÿ å¸ç‹ä¸ç›¸è¥²ï¼Œä½•ç¦®ä¹‹å¾ªï¼Ÿ è™™æˆ²ã€ç¥è¾²æ•™è€Œä¸èª…ï¼Œé»ƒå¸ã€å ¯ã€èˆœèª…è€Œä¸æ€’ã€‚ åŠè‡³ä¸‰ç‹ï¼Œéš¨æ™‚åˆ¶æ³•ï¼Œå› äº‹åˆ¶ç¦®ã€‚ æ³•åº¦åˆ¶ä»¤å„é †å…¶å®œï¼Œè¡£æœå™¨æ¢°å„ä¾¿å…¶ç”¨ã€‚ æ•…ç¦®ä¹Ÿä¸å¿…ä¸€é“ï¼Œè€Œä¾¿åœ‹ä¸å¿…å¤ã€‚ è–äººä¹‹èˆˆä¹Ÿä¸ç›¸è¥²è€Œç‹ï¼Œå¤ã€æ®·ä¹‹è¡°ä¹Ÿä¸æ˜“ç¦®è€Œæ»…ã€‚ ç„¶å‰‡åå¤æœªå¯éï¼Œè€Œå¾ªç¦®æœªè¶³å¤šä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸”æœå¥‡è€…å¿—æ·«ï¼Œå‰‡æ˜¯é„’ã€é­¯ç„¡å¥‡è¡Œä¹Ÿï¼› ä¿—è¾Ÿè€…æ°‘æ˜“ï¼Œå‰‡æ˜¯å³ã€è¶Šç„¡ç§€å£«ä¹Ÿã€‚ ä¸”è–äººåˆ©èº«è¬‚ä¹‹æœï¼Œä¾¿äº‹è¬‚ä¹‹ç¦®ã€‚ å¤«é€²é€€ä¹‹ç¯€ï¼Œè¡£æœä¹‹åˆ¶è€…ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥é½Šå¸¸æ°‘ä¹Ÿï¼Œéæ‰€ä»¥è«–è³¢è€…ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ•…é½Šæ°‘èˆ‡ä¿—æµï¼Œè³¢è€…èˆ‡è®Šä¿±ã€‚ æ•…è«ºæ›°ã€ä»¥æ›¸å¾¡è€…ä¸ç›¡é¦¬ä¹‹æƒ…ï¼Œä»¥å¤åˆ¶ä»Šè€…ä¸é”äº‹ä¹‹è®Šã€ã€‚ å¾ªæ³•ä¹‹åŠŸï¼Œä¸è¶³ä»¥é«˜ä¸–ï¼› æ³•å¤ä¹‹å­¸ï¼Œä¸è¶³ä»¥åˆ¶ä»Šã€‚ å­ä¸åŠä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ é‚èƒ¡æœæ‹›é¨å°„ã€‚
Zhao Wen, Zhao Zao, Zhou Shan, and Zhao Jun all advised to stop the Wang from adopting Hu clothing, saying the old law was convenient. The Wang said: 'Former kings did not have the same customs. What is ancient law? Di and Wang do not mutually follow each other. What rites should be followed? Fu Xi and Shen Nong taught without punishing. Huang Di, Yao, and Shun punished without getting angry. When it reached the three Wang, they followed the time to make law and relied on affairs to make rites. Laws, measures, and commands each follow what is suitable. Clothing and weapons each are convenient for their use. Therefore rites are not necessarily one way, and what is convenient for the country is not necessarily ancient. When sages rose they did not mutually follow each other to become Wang. When Xia and Yin declined they did not change rites and perish. Thus opposing the ancient is not condemnable, while following rites is not sufficient for praise. Moreover, those who wear strange clothing have licentious wills, but then Zou and Lu would have no strange conduct; Those whose customs are deviant have easy people, but then Wu and Yue would have no excellent scholars. Moreover, sages call what benefits the body 'clothing,' and what makes affairs convenient 'rites.' Indeed, the sections of advance and retreat, the regulations of clothing - these regulate the common people, not discuss the worthy. Therefore regulate the people with the flow of custom, and the worthy go together with change. Therefore the proverb says: 'Using a book to drive does not exhaust the horse's feelings. Using the ancient to control the present does not reach the affairs' change.' Following the law's merit is not sufficient to be high in the world; Modeling ancient learning is not sufficient to control the present. You do not reach it.' He then adopted Hu clothing and recruited for riding and shooting.

In the twentieth year, the Wang raided Zhongshan's lands and reached Ning Jia; He raided Hu lands to the west and reached Yu Zhong. The Lin Hu Wang offered horses. He returned and sent Lou Huan to Qin, Qiu Ye to Han, Wang Ben to Chu, Fu Ding to Wei, and Zhao Jue to Qi. Dai chancellor Zhao Gu governed the Hu and brought their troops.

äºŒåä¸€å¹´ï¼Œæ”»ä¸­å±±ã€‚ è¶™è¢‘ç‚ºå³è»ï¼Œè¨±éˆç‚ºå·¦è»ï¼Œå…¬å­ç« ç‚ºä¸­è»ï¼Œç‹å¹¶å°‡ä¹‹ã€‚ ç‰›ç¿¦å°‡è»Šé¨ï¼Œè¶™å¸Œå¹¶å°‡èƒ¡ã€ä»£ã€‚ è¶™èˆ‡ä¹‹é™˜ï¼Œåˆè»æ›²é™½ï¼Œæ”»å–ä¸¹ä¸˜ã€è¯é™½ã€é´Ÿä¹‹å¡ã€‚ ç‹è»å–é„—ã€çŸ³é‚‘ã€å°é¾ã€æ±å£ã€‚ ä¸­å±±ç»å››é‚‘å’Œï¼Œç‹è¨±ä¹‹ï¼Œç½·å…µã€‚ äºŒåä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ”»ä¸­å±±ã€‚ äºŒåäº”å¹´ï¼Œæƒ åå’ã€‚ ä½¿å‘¨è¢‘èƒ¡æœå‚…ç‹å­ä½•ã€‚ äºŒåå…­å¹´ï¼Œå¾©æ”»ä¸­å±±ï¼Œæ”˜åœ°åŒ—è‡³ç‡•ã€ä»£ï¼Œè¥¿è‡³é›²ä¸­ã€ä¹åŸã€‚
In the twenty-first year, he attacked Zhongshan. Zhao Dan was the right army, Xu Jun the left army, Prince Zhang the middle army. The Wang commanded them together. Niu Jian commanded the chariots and cavalry. Zhao Xi together commanded the Hu and Dai. Zhao met them at Xing, combined the army at Qu Yang, and attacked to take Dan Qiu, Hua Yang, and Chi's barrier. The Wang's army took Hao, Shi Yi, Feng Long, and Dong Yuan. Zhongshan offered four cities for peace. The Wang permitted it and stopped the troops. In the twenty-third year, he attacked Zhongshan. In the twenty-fifth year, Hui Hou died. He sent Zhou Shan, who was Hu clothed, to instruct Prince Zi He. In the twenty-sixth year, he again attacked Zhongshan and seized lands north to Yan and Dai, west to Yun Zhong and Jiu Yuan.

äºŒåä¸ƒå¹´äº”æœˆæˆŠç”³ï¼Œå¤§æœæ–¼æ±å®®ï¼Œå‚³åœ‹ï¼Œç«‹ç‹å­ä½•ä»¥ç‚ºç‹ã€‚ ç‹å»Ÿè¦‹ç¦®ç•¢ï¼Œå‡ºè‡¨æœã€‚ å¤§å¤«æ‚‰ç‚ºè‡£ï¼Œè‚¥ç¾©ç‚ºç›¸åœ‹ï¼Œå¹¶å‚…ç‹ã€‚ æ˜¯ç‚ºæƒ æ–‡ç‹ã€‚ æƒ æ–‡ç‹ï¼Œæƒ åå³å¨ƒå­ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ­¦éˆç‹è‡ªè™Ÿç‚ºä¸»çˆ¶ã€‚
In the twenty-seventh year, fifth month, Wu Shen, great court at the east palace, transmitted the state, and established Prince Zi He as Wang. The Wang had temple audience, rites finished, and went out to attend court. All grandees became ministers. Fei Yi became chancellor and together instructed the Wang. This was Hui Wen Wang. Hui Wen Wang was Hui Hou Wu Wa's son. Wu Ling Wang self-called himself Lord Father.

Lord Father desired to make his son mainly govern the country, but himself, Hu clothed, led the scholar officials to raid Hu lands northwest, and desired to attack Qin straight south from Yun Zhong and Jiu Yuan. Thereupon he deceived himself as an envoy and entered Qin. Qin Zhao Wang did not know. Afterwards he was strange at his very great appearance, not a minister's measure. He sent people to pursue him, but Lord Father had already galloped and escaped the pass. He carefully questioned it and it was Lord Father. The Qin people were greatly startled. The reason Lord Father entered Qin was that he desired to survey the terrain himself, and thus observe Qin Wang's character.

ä¸‰å¹´ï¼Œæ»…ä¸­å±±ï¼Œé·å…¶ç‹æ–¼è†šæ–½ã€‚ èµ·éˆå£½ï¼ŒåŒ—åœ°æ–¹å¾ï¼Œä»£é“å¤§é€šã€‚ é‚„æ­¸ï¼Œè¡Œè³ï¼Œå¤§èµ¦ï¼Œç½®é…’é…ºäº”æ—¥ï¼Œå°é•·å­ç« ç‚ºä»£å®‰é™½å›ã€‚ ç« ç´ ä¾ˆï¼Œå¿ƒä¸æœå…¶å¼Ÿæ‰€ç«‹ã€‚ ä¸»çˆ¶åˆä½¿ç”°ä¸ç¦®ç›¸ç« ä¹Ÿã€‚
In the third year, he extinguished Zhongshan and moved their Wang to Fu Shi. He raised Ling Shou. The northern lands followed. Dai roads were greatly open. He returned home, gave rewards, granted great amnesty, placed wine feasts for five days, and enfeoffed eldest son Zhang as Dai An Yang Jun. Zhang was always extravagant. His heart did not submit to his younger brother's establishment. Lord Father moreover sent Tian Bu Li to assist Zhang.

æå…Œè¬‚è‚¥ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œå…¬å­ç« å½Šå£¯è€Œå¿—é©•ï¼Œé»¨çœ¾è€Œæ¬²å¤§ï¼Œæ®†æœ‰ç§ä¹ï¼Ÿ ç”°ä¸ç¦®ä¹‹ç‚ºäººä¹Ÿï¼Œå¿æ®ºè€Œé©•ã€‚ äºŒäººç›¸å¾—ï¼Œå¿…æœ‰è¬€é™°è³Šèµ·ï¼Œä¸€å‡ºèº«å¾¼å¹¸ã€‚ å¤«å°äººæœ‰æ¬²ï¼Œè¼•æ…®æ·ºè¬€ï¼Œå¾’è¦‹å…¶åˆ©è€Œä¸é¡§å…¶å®³ï¼ŒåŒé¡ç›¸æ¨ï¼Œä¿±å…¥ç¦é–€ã€‚ ä»¥å¾è§€ä¹‹ï¼Œå¿…ä¸ä¹…çŸ£ã€‚ å­ä»»é‡è€Œå‹¢å¤§ï¼Œäº‚ä¹‹æ‰€å§‹ï¼Œç¦ä¹‹æ‰€é›†ä¹Ÿï¼Œå­å¿…å…ˆæ‚£ã€‚ ä»è€…æ„›è¬ç‰©è€Œæ™ºè€…å‚™ç¦æ–¼æœªå½¢ï¼Œä¸ä»ä¸æ™ºï¼Œä½•ä»¥ç‚ºåœ‹ï¼Ÿ å­å¥šä¸ç¨±ç–¾æ¯‹å‡ºï¼Œå‚³æ”¿æ–¼å…¬å­æˆï¼Ÿ æ¯‹ç‚ºæ€¨åºœï¼Œæ¯‹ç‚ºç¦æ¢¯ã€‚ã€ è‚¥ç¾©æ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸å¯ï¼Œæ˜”è€…ä¸»çˆ¶ä»¥ç‹å±¬ç¾©ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€æ¯‹è®Šè€Œåº¦ï¼Œæ¯‹ç•°è€Œæ…®ï¼Œå …å®ˆä¸€å¿ƒï¼Œä»¥æ­¿è€Œä¸–ã€‚ã€ ç¾©å†æ‹œå—å‘½è€Œç±ä¹‹ã€‚ ä»Šç•ä¸ç¦®ä¹‹é›£è€Œå¿˜å¾ç±ï¼Œè®Šå­°å¤§ç„‰ã€‚ é€²å—åš´å‘½ï¼Œé€€è€Œä¸å…¨ï¼Œè² å­°ç”šç„‰ã€‚ è®Šè² ä¹‹è‡£ï¼Œä¸å®¹æ–¼åˆ‘ã€‚ è«ºæ›°ã€æ­»è€…å¾©ç”Ÿï¼Œç”Ÿè€…ä¸æ„§ã€ã€‚ å¾è¨€å·²åœ¨å‰çŸ£ï¼Œå¾æ¬²å…¨å¾è¨€ï¼Œå®‰å¾—å…¨å¾èº«ï¼ ä¸”å¤«è²è‡£ä¹Ÿé›£è‡³è€Œç¯€è¦‹ï¼Œå¿ è‡£ä¹Ÿç´¯è‡³è€Œè¡Œæ˜ã€‚ å­å‰‡æœ‰è³œè€Œå¿ æˆ‘çŸ£ï¼Œé›–ç„¶ï¼Œå¾æœ‰èªåœ¨å‰è€…ä¹Ÿï¼Œçµ‚ä¸æ•¢å¤±ã€‚ã€ æå…Œæ›°ï¼šã€Œè«¾ï¼Œå­å‹‰ä¹‹çŸ£ï¼ å¾è¦‹å­å·²ä»Šå¹´è€³ã€‚ã€ æ¶•æ³£è€Œå‡ºã€‚ æå…Œæ•¸è¦‹å…¬å­æˆï¼Œä»¥å‚™ç”°ä¸ç¦®ä¹‹äº‹ã€‚
Li Dui told Fei Yi: 'Prince Zhang is strong and robust but his will is arrogant. His faction is numerous and his desires are great. Perhaps he has private ambitions? Tian Bu Li's character endures killing and is arrogant. The two people are mutually agreeable. They certainly have plotted secret villainy to arise, once using their bodies to seek fortune. Indeed small people have desires. Their considerations are light and plots shallow. They only see benefits and do not regard harms. Those of the same kind mutually push each other. They together enter the calamity gate. With my observation, it certainly will not be long. Your responsibility is heavy and authority great. It is where rebellion starts and calamity gathers. You will certainly suffer first. The benevolent love the ten thousand things while the wise prepare for calamity before it is formed. If not benevolent and not wise, how to govern the country? Why don't you claim illness and not go out, transmit governance to Prince Cheng? Do not become a treasury of resentment, do not become a ladder of calamity.' Fei Yi said: 'Cannot. Formerly Lord Father entrusted the Wang to Yi and said: 'Do not change the measure, do not consider differently, firmly guard one heart, until death through generations.' Yi bowed twice, received the command, and recorded it. Now fearing Bu Li's difficulty and forgetting my record - what change is greater. I advanced and received the strict command. If I retreat and do not complete it, what betrayal is greater. A minister who changes and betrays is not tolerated by punishment. The proverb says: 'The dead live again, the living are not ashamed.' My words are already spoken before. I desire to complete my words. How can I obtain to complete my body! Moreover, for a faithful minister, when difficulty arrives, integrity appears. For a loyal minister, when troubles arrive, conduct becomes clear. You then have reward and are loyal to me. Although that is so, I have words spoken before. I finally dare not lose them.' Li Dui said: 'Yes, you strive! I will see you already this year.' He wept tears and went out. Li Dui repeatedly saw Prince Cheng to prepare for Tian Bu Li's affairs.

ç•°æ—¥è‚¥ç¾©è¬‚ä¿¡æœŸæ›°ï¼šã€Œå…¬å­èˆ‡ç”°ä¸ç¦®ç”šå¯æ†‚ä¹Ÿã€‚ å…¶æ–¼ç¾©ä¹Ÿè²å–„è€Œå¯¦æƒ¡ï¼Œæ­¤ç‚ºäººä¹Ÿä¸å­ä¸è‡£ã€‚ å¾èä¹‹ä¹Ÿï¼Œå§¦è‡£åœ¨æœï¼Œåœ‹ä¹‹æ®˜ä¹Ÿï¼› è®’è‡£åœ¨ä¸­ï¼Œä¸»ä¹‹è ¹ä¹Ÿã€‚ æ­¤äººè²ªè€Œæ¬²å¤§ï¼Œå…§å¾—ä¸»è€Œå¤–ç‚ºæš´ã€‚ çŸ¯ä»¤ç‚ºæ…¢ï¼Œä»¥æ“…ä¸€æ—¦ä¹‹å‘½ï¼Œä¸é›£ç‚ºä¹Ÿï¼Œç¦ä¸”é€®åœ‹ã€‚ ä»Šå¾æ†‚ä¹‹ï¼Œå¤œè€Œå¿˜å¯ï¼Œé¥‘è€Œå¿˜é£Ÿã€‚ ç›œè³Šå‡ºå…¥ä¸å¯ä¸å‚™ã€‚ è‡ªä»Šä»¥ä¾†ï¼Œè‹¥æœ‰å¬ç‹è€…å¿…è¦‹å¾é¢ï¼Œæˆ‘å°‡å…ˆä»¥èº«ç•¶ä¹‹ï¼Œç„¡æ•…è€Œç‹ä¹ƒå…¥ã€‚ã€ ä¿¡æœŸæ›°ï¼šã€Œå–„å“‰ï¼Œå¾å¾—èæ­¤ä¹Ÿï¼ã€
Another day Fei Yi told Xin Qi: 'The prince with Tian Bu Li is very worrisome. His righteousness has a good voice but evil reality. This person is neither son nor minister. I have heard that villainous ministers in court are the country's ruin; Slanderous ministers in the center are the lord's borers. This person is greedy and desires greatness. He obtains the lord inwardly but does violence outwardly. He falsely commands to be slow and monopolizes one morning's command. It is not difficult to do. Calamity will moreover reach the country. Now I worry about it. At night I forget to sleep. When hungry I forget to eat. Robbers and bandits entering and exiting cannot not be prepared for. From now henceforth, if there is someone who summons the Wang, they must see my face. I will first block it with my body. Only if there is no reason may the Wang enter.' Xin Qi said: 'Good! I obtained to hear this!'

å››å¹´ï¼Œæœç¾¤è‡£ï¼Œå®‰é™½å›äº¦ä¾†æœã€‚ ä¸»çˆ¶ä»¤ç‹è½æœï¼Œè€Œè‡ªå¾æ—è§€çªºç¾¤è‡£å®—å®¤ä¹‹ç¦®ã€‚ è¦‹å…¶é•·å­ç« å‚«ç„¶ä¹Ÿï¼ŒååŒ—é¢ç‚ºè‡£ï¼Œè©˜æ–¼å…¶å¼Ÿï¼Œå¿ƒæ†ä¹‹ï¼Œæ–¼æ˜¯ä¹ƒæ¬²åˆ†è¶™è€Œç‹ç« æ–¼ä»£ï¼Œè¨ˆæœªæ±ºè€Œè¼Ÿã€‚
In the fourth year, he held court for the group of ministers. An Yang Jun also came to court. Lord Father commanded the Wang to listen to court, but himself observed and spied on the group of ministers' clan chambers' rites from the side. ä¸»çˆ¶åŠç‹æ¸¸æ²™ä¸˜ï¼Œç•°å®®ï¼Œå…¬å­ç« å³ä»¥å…¶å¾’èˆ‡ç”°ä¸ç¦®ä½œäº‚ï¼Œè©ä»¥ä¸»çˆ¶ä»¤å¬ç‹ã€‚ è‚¥ç¾©å…ˆå…¥ï¼Œæ®ºä¹‹ã€‚ é«˜ä¿¡å³èˆ‡ç‹æˆ°ã€‚ å…¬å­æˆèˆ‡æå…Œè‡ªåœ‹è‡³ï¼Œä¹ƒèµ·å››é‚‘ä¹‹å…µå…¥è·é›£ï¼Œæ®ºå…¬å­ç« åŠç”°ä¸ç¦®ï¼Œæ»…å…¶é»¨è³Šè€Œå®šç‹å®¤ã€‚ å…¬å­æˆç‚ºç›¸ï¼Œè™Ÿå®‰å¹³å›ï¼Œæå…Œç‚ºå¸å¯‡ã€‚ å…¬å­ç« ä¹‹æ•—ï¼Œå¾€èµ°ä¸»çˆ¶ï¼Œä¸»ä¸»é–‹ä¹‹ï¼Œæˆã€å…Œå› åœä¸»çˆ¶å®®ã€‚ å…¬å­ç« æ­»ï¼Œå…¬å­æˆã€æå…Œè¬€æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»¥ç« æ•…åœä¸»çˆ¶ï¼Œå³è§£å…µï¼Œå¾å±¬å¤·çŸ£ã€‚ã€ ä¹ƒé‚åœä¸»çˆ¶ã€‚ ä»¤å®®ä¸­äººã€Œå¾Œå‡ºè€…å¤·ã€ï¼Œå®®ä¸­äººæ‚‰å‡ºã€‚ ä¸»çˆ¶æ¬²å‡ºä¸å¾—ï¼Œåˆä¸å¾—é£Ÿï¼Œæ¢çˆµé·‡è€Œé£Ÿä¹‹ï¼Œä¸‰æœˆé¤˜è€Œé¤“æ­»æ²™ä¸˜å®®ã€‚ ä¸»çˆ¶å®šæ­»ï¼Œä¹ƒç™¼å–ªèµ´è«¸ä¾¯ã€‚
Lord Father and the Wang toured Sha Qiu in separate palaces. Prince Zhang immediately, with his followers and Tian Bu Li, made rebellion and deceived by using Lord Father's command to summon the Wang. Fei Yi entered first and killed him. Gao Xin immediately fought with the Wang. Prince Cheng and Li Dui arrived from the country. They then raised troops from four cities and entered to resist the difficulty. They killed Prince Zhang and Tian Bu Li, extinguished their faction of traitors, and stabilized the wang chamber. Prince Cheng became chancellor and was titled An Ping Jun. Li Dui became chief judge. Prince Zhang's defeat caused him to go and flee to Lord Father. Lord Father opened the gate for him. Cheng and Dui thus surrounded Lord Father's palace. Prince Zhang died. Prince Cheng and Li Dui plotted, saying: 'Because of Zhang, we surrounded Lord Father. If we immediately disband the troops, our group will be exterminated.' They then thus surrounded Lord Father. They commanded the palace people: 'Those who exit later will have their families destroyed.' The palace people all exited. Lord Father desired to exit but was not able. He moreover could not obtain food. He groped for wine cups and sparrows and ate them. After three months remaining, he starved to death in the Sha Qiu palace. Lord Father certainly died. They then issued mourning and hastened to the feudal lords.

å­æˆç‹å…ƒå¹´ï¼Œç§¦ä¼æˆ‘ï¼Œæ‹”ä¸‰åŸã€‚ è¶™ç‹æ–°ç«‹ï¼Œå¤ªåç”¨äº‹ï¼Œç§¦æ€¥æ”»ä¹‹ã€‚ è¶™æ°æ±‚æ•‘æ–¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šæ›°ï¼šã€Œå¿…ä»¥é•·å®‰å›ç‚ºè³ªï¼Œå…µä¹ƒå‡ºã€‚ã€ å¤ªåä¸è‚¯ï¼Œå¤§è‡£å½Šè««ã€‚ å¤ªåæ˜è¬‚å·¦å³æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾©è¨€é•·å®‰å›ç‚ºè³ªè€…ï¼Œè€å©¦å¿…å”¾å…¶é¢ã€‚ã€ å·¦å¸«è§¸é¾è¨€é¡˜è¦‹å¤ªåï¼Œå¤ªåç››æ°£è€Œèƒ¥ä¹‹ã€‚ å…¥ï¼Œå¾è¶¨è€Œåï¼Œè‡ªè¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£ç—…è¶³ï¼Œæ›¾ä¸èƒ½ç–¾èµ°ï¼Œä¸å¾—è¦‹ä¹…çŸ£ã€‚ ç«Šè‡ªæ•ï¼Œè€Œæå¤ªåé«”ä¹‹æœ‰æ‰€è‹¦ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ•…é¡˜æœ›è¦‹å¤ªåã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œè€å©¦æƒè¼¦è€Œè¡Œè€³ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œé£Ÿå¾—æ¯‹è¡°ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œæƒç²¥è€³ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£é–’è€…æ®Šä¸æ¬²é£Ÿï¼Œä¹ƒå½Šæ­¥ï¼Œæ—¥ä¸‰å››é‡Œï¼Œå°‘ç›Šå—œé£Ÿï¼Œå’Œæ–¼èº«ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œè€å©¦ä¸èƒ½ã€‚ã€ å¤ªåä¸å’Œä¹‹è‰²å°‘è§£ã€‚ å·¦å¸«å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£è³¤æ¯èˆ’ç¥ºæœ€å°‘ï¼Œä¸è‚–ï¼Œè€Œè‡£è¡°ï¼Œç«Šæ†æ„›ä¹‹ï¼Œé¡˜å¾—è£œé»‘è¡£ä¹‹ç¼ºä»¥è¡›ç‹å®®ï¼Œæ˜§æ­»ä»¥èã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œæ•¬è«¾ã€‚ å¹´å¹¾ä½•çŸ£ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œåäº”æ­²çŸ£ã€‚ é›–å°‘ï¼Œé¡˜åŠæœªå¡«æºå£‘è€Œè¨—ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œä¸ˆå¤«äº¦æ„›æ†å°‘å­ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œç”šæ–¼å©¦äººã€‚ã€ å¤ªåç¬‘æ›°ï¼šã€Œå©¦äººç•°ç”šã€‚ã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€è‡£ç«Šä»¥ç‚ºåª¼ä¹‹æ„›ç‡•åè³¢æ–¼é•·å®‰å›ã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œå›éçŸ£ï¼Œä¸è‹¥é•·å®‰å›ä¹‹ç”šã€‚ã€ å·¦å¸«å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œçˆ¶æ¯æ„›å­å‰‡ç‚ºä¹‹è¨ˆæ·±é ã€‚ åª¼ä¹‹é€ç‡•åä¹Ÿï¼ŒæŒå…¶è¸µï¼Œç‚ºä¹‹æ³£ï¼Œå¿µå…¶é ä¹Ÿï¼Œäº¦å“€ä¹‹çŸ£ã€‚ å·²è¡Œï¼Œéä¸æ€ä¹Ÿï¼Œç¥­ç¥€å‰‡ç¥ä¹‹æ›°ã€å¿…å‹¿ä½¿åã€ï¼Œè±ˆéè¨ˆé•·ä¹…ï¼Œç‚ºå­å­«ç›¸ç¹¼ç‚ºç‹ä¹Ÿå“‰ï¼Ÿã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¶ã€‚ã€ å·¦å¸«å…¬æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šä¸‰ä¸–ä»¥å‰ï¼Œè‡³æ–¼è¶™ä¸»ä¹‹å­å­«ç‚ºä¾¯è€…ï¼Œå…¶ç¹¼æœ‰åœ¨è€…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œç„¡æœ‰ã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¾®ç¨è¶™ï¼Œè«¸ä¾¯æœ‰åœ¨è€…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œè€å©¦ä¸èä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ æ›°ï¼šã€Œæ­¤å…¶è¿‘è€…ç¦åŠå…¶èº«ï¼Œé è€…åŠå…¶å­å­«ã€‚ è±ˆäººä¸»ä¹‹å­ä¾¯å‰‡ä¸å–„å“‰ï¼Ÿ ä½å°Šè€Œç„¡åŠŸï¼Œå¥‰åšè€Œç„¡å‹ï¼Œè€ŒæŒ¾é‡å™¨å¤šä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šåª¼å°Šé•·å®‰å›ä¹‹ä½ï¼Œè€Œå°ä¹‹ä»¥è†è…´ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå¤šèˆ‡ä¹‹é‡å™¨ï¼Œè€Œä¸åŠä»Šä»¤æœ‰åŠŸæ–¼åœ‹ï¼Œä¸€æ—¦å±±é™µå´©ï¼Œé•·å®‰å›ä½•ä»¥è‡ªè¨—æ–¼è¶™ï¼Ÿ è€è‡£ä»¥åª¼ç‚ºé•·å®‰å›ä¹‹è¨ˆçŸ­ä¹Ÿï¼Œæ•…ä»¥ç‚ºæ„›ä¹‹ä¸è‹¥ç‡•åã€‚ã€ å¤ªåæ›°ï¼šã€Œè«¾ï¼Œæ£å›ä¹‹æ‰€ä½¿ä¹‹ã€‚ã€ æ–¼æ˜¯ç‚ºé•·å®‰å›ç´„è»Šç™¾ä¹˜ï¼Œè³ªæ–¼é½Šï¼Œé½Šå…µä¹ƒå‡ºã€‚
In Xiao Cheng Wang's first year, Qin attacked us and captured three cities. Zhao Wang was newly established. The empress dowager managed affairs. Qin urgently attacked it. The Zhao clan sought aid from Qi. Qi said: 'Must use Chang An Jun as hostage, then troops will go out.' The empress dowager was not willing. Ministers strongly advised. The empress dowager clearly told her attendants: 'Whoever again speaks of Chang An Jun as hostage, this old woman will certainly spit on his face.' Left tutor Chu Long said he wished to see the empress dowager. The empress dowager, angry, waited for him. He entered, slowly approached and sat. He apologized to himself, saying: 'Old minister's feet are ill. Once I could not quickly walk. I have not been seen for a long time.' I secretly excused myself, but feared the empress dowager's body had some suffering. Therefore I wished to see the empress dowager.' The empress dowager said: 'This old woman relies on a palanquin to walk.' He said: 'Is your food intake not declining?' She said: 'I rely on congee.' He said: 'Recently the old minister particularly did not desire food. Then I forced myself to walk, three or four li daily. It slightly increased my appetite for food and harmonized my body.' The empress dowager said: 'This old woman cannot.' The empress dowager's unpleasant expression slightly relaxed. Left tutor duke said: 'The old minister's lowly son Shu Qi is the youngest and unworthy. But the minister is aged and secretly pities and loves him. I wish to obtain filling the black clothes vacancy to guard the wang palace. I risk death to hear this.' The empress dowager said: 'Respectfully yes. How old is he?' He replied: 'Fifteen years old. Though young, I wish to entrust him before he fills the ditches and mounds.' The empress dowager said: 'Do husbands also pity their young sons?' He replied: 'More than women.' The empress dowager laughed and said: 'Women are very different.' He replied: 'The old minister secretly thinks your love for the Yan queen is superior to Chang An Jun.' The empress dowager said: 'You are mistaken, sir. It is not equal to Chang An Jun so much.' Left tutor duke said: 'When parents love their son, they plan deeply and far for him. When you sent the Yan queen, you held her heels and cried for her. Thinking of how far away she would be, you also pitied her. She had already gone. It was not that you did not think of her. At sacrifices you prayed, 'Certainly do not make her return.' Was this not planning for the long term, so that descendants could successively be wang?' The empress dowager said: 'So.' Left tutor duke said: 'Now, going back three generations, down to the Zhao lords' sons and descendants who were enfeoffed as hou - do their successors still exist?' She said: 'None have.' He said: 'Not only Zhao - do other feudal lords have survivors?' She said: 'This old woman has not heard.' He said: 'The near ones' calamity reached their own bodies. The far ones' reached their descendants. Is it that lords' sons who are enfeoffed as hou are not good? Their position is honored but without merit. Their salary is thick but without toil. Yet they hold many heavy vessels. Now you honor Chang An Jun's position and enfeoff him with fertile lands. You give him many heavy vessels, but you do not reach the point of now making him have merit to the state. Once the mountain tomb collapses, how will Chang An Jun entrust himself to Zhao? The old minister thinks your planning for Chang An Jun is short. Therefore I think your love for him does not equal that for the Yan queen.' The empress dowager said: 'Yes. Let the sir do as he wishes.' Thereupon they prepared one hundred chariots for Chang An Jun and made him hostage to Qi. Qi troops then went out.

Qi An Ping Jun Tian Dan led Zhao troops and attacked Yan's Zhong Yang, capturing it. He again attacked Han's Zhu Ren and captured it. In the second year, Hui Wen queen died. Tian Dan became chancellor.

In the fourth year, the wang dreamed he wore a one-sided fur coat and rode a flying dragon ascending to heaven. He did not reach it and fell. He saw gold and jade accumulated like a mountain. The next day, the wang summoned diviner Gan to divine it. He said: 'Dreaming of wearing a one-sided fur coat means remnant.' Riding a flying dragon ascending heaven but not reaching and falling means having air but no substance. Seeing gold and jade accumulated like a mountain means worry.'

å¾Œä¸‰æ—¥ï¼ŒéŸ“æ°ä¸Šé»¨å®ˆé¦®äº­ä½¿è€…è‡³ï¼Œæ›°ï¼šã€ŒéŸ“ä¸èƒ½å®ˆä¸Šé»¨ï¼Œå…¥ä¹‹æ–¼ç§¦ã€‚ å…¶åæ°‘çš†å®‰ç‚ºè¶™ï¼Œä¸æ¬²ç‚ºç§¦ã€‚ æœ‰åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒï¼Œé¡˜å†æ‹œå…¥ä¹‹è¶™ï¼Œè²¡ç‹æ‰€ä»¥è³œåæ°‘ã€‚ã€ ç‹å¤§å–œï¼Œå¬å¹³é™½å›è±¹å‘Šä¹‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œé¦®äº­å…¥åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒï¼Œå—ä¹‹ä½•å¦‚ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œè–äººç”šç¦ç„¡æ•…ä¹‹åˆ©ã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œäººæ‡·å¾å¾·ï¼Œä½•è¬‚ç„¡æ•…ä¹ï¼Ÿã€ å°æ›°ï¼šã€Œå¤«ç§¦è ¶é£ŸéŸ“æ°åœ°ï¼Œä¸­çµ•ä¸ä»¤ç›¸é€šï¼Œå›ºè‡ªä»¥ç‚ºåè€Œå—ä¸Šé»¨ä¹‹åœ°ä¹Ÿã€‚ éŸ“æ°æ‰€ä»¥ä¸å…¥æ–¼ç§¦è€…ï¼Œæ¬²å«å…¶ç¦æ–¼è¶™ä¹Ÿã€‚ ç§¦æœå…¶å‹è€Œè¶™å—å…¶åˆ©ï¼Œé›–å½Šå¤§ä¸èƒ½å¾—ä¹‹æ–¼å°å¼±ï¼Œå°å¼±é¡§èƒ½å¾—ä¹‹æ–¼å½Šå¤§ä¹ï¼Ÿ è±ˆå¯è¬‚éç„¡æ•…ä¹‹åˆ©å“‰ï¼ ä¸”å¤«ç§¦ä»¥ç‰›ç”°ä¹‹æ°´é€šç³§è ¶é£Ÿï¼Œä¸Šä¹˜å€æˆ°è€…ï¼Œè£‚ä¸Šåœ‹ä¹‹åœ°ï¼Œå…¶æ”¿è¡Œï¼Œä¸å¯èˆ‡ç‚ºé›£ï¼Œå¿…å‹¿å—ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€ ç‹æ›°ï¼šã€Œä»Šç™¼ç™¾è¬ä¹‹è»è€Œæ”»ï¼Œè¸°å¹´æ­·æ­²æœªå¾—ä¸€åŸä¹Ÿã€‚ ä»Šä»¥åŸå¸‚é‚‘åä¸ƒå¹£å¾åœ‹ï¼Œæ­¤å¤§åˆ©ä¹Ÿã€‚ã€
After three days, the Han clan's Shang Dang governor Feng Ting's envoy arrived and said: 'Han cannot guard Shang Dang and will enter it to Qin. Its officials and people are all content to be Zhao and do not wish to be Qin. It has seventeen cities and towns. We wish to repeatedly bow and enter them to Zhao, and moreover the wang should reward the officials and people accordingly.' The wang was greatly happy. He summoned Ping Yang Jun Bao and told him: 'Feng Ting enters seventeen cities and towns. How about accepting it?' He replied: 'Sages greatly fear profit without cause.' The wang said: 'People cherish my virtue. How is this called without cause?' He replied: 'Indeed Qin silkworm-eats Han clan's lands. It cuts in the middle and does not let them connect. It certainly thinks it will seated receive Shang Dang's lands.' The Han clan's reason for not entering to Qin is that it desires to marry its calamity to Zhao. Qin bears its toil and Zhao receives its benefit. Though the strong and big cannot obtain it from the small and weak, can the small and weak moreover obtain it from the strong and big? How can this be called anything but profit without cause! Moreover, Qin transports grain with Niu Tian water and silkworm-eats. Its upper chariots have double warriors. It splits superior state lands. Its governance is effective. One cannot contend with it. Certainly do not accept.' The wang said: 'Now dispatching a million-man army to attack, passing years through years without obtaining one city.' Now enriching my state with seventeen cities and towns - this is great benefit.'
